title: State v. Young
description: In this criminal sexual conduct case, the majority of the Court reviews the "door opening" principle with specificity, and the dissent discusses the prejudicial impact of similar convictions.

Young was charged with possession with intent to distribute crack cocaine, criminal sexual conduct in the first degree, and kidnapping.Â  He pled guilty to the possession charge, and a jury convicted him of kidnapping, and of assault and battery of a high and aggravated nature as a lesser included offense of criminal sexual conduct.Â  On appeal, Young argues (1) the trial judge erred by admitting evidence of his prior convictions for criminal sexual conduct and criminal domestic violence, and (2) the State improperly injected race as a motive.Â  We affirm.Â  
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Young was accused of kidnapping and raping the victim in the early morning hours of September 9, 2001, in downtown Charleston, South Carolina.Â  Following dinner the previous evening, the victim drove downtown by herself to purchase crack cocaine.Â  She testified she had done this numerous times before.Â  The victim bought crack cocaine on this particular night from Young because he â€œlooked familiar to [her], like [she] had bought from him before.â€Â  After purchasing crack from Young, the victim smoked it and asked to buy more.Â  He indicated he needed a ride to get more crack, and she agreed to drive him.Â  Young became enraged when the victim informed Young she wanted more crack so that she could return home and smoke it with her husband.Â  She alleges Young hit her, forced his way into the driverâ€™s seat, drove to a secluded area, and raped her.Â  
At approximately nine oâ€™clock a.m., Corporal Sherry Niblock spotted the victimâ€™s car parked and observed the victim fully reclined in the passenger seat with Young on top of her.Â  When Young saw Niblock, he jumped into the driverâ€™s seat and sped away in the vehicle.Â  Niblock testified that the victim looked exhausted, had been crying, and had bruises on her neck.Â  Niblock stated the victim â€œrolled her head over at [her] and said, â€˜Would you please just help me?â€™â€Â  Niblock dispatched information about the vehicle, which Officer Peter Hall located approximately ten minutes later.Â  According to Hall, the victim looked exhausted and had marks on her neck and wrists.Â  A rape exam was inconclusive as to whether sexual assault had occurred.Â  
Young testified at trial and gave a much different account of his encounter with the victim on the night in question.Â  According to Young, the victim was one of his customers.Â  He stated the two of them drove around all night smoking crack and talking.Â  
Throughout his testimony, Young conveyed his concernment for the victimâ€™s safety.Â  He averred that he had previously sold drugs to the victim and on the night of the alleged rape, she returned to the place they had first met and asked for him.Â  Young proclaimed he sold her $80 worth of crack, which the two of them smoked.Â  After consuming the crack, the victim asked for more.Â  Young recounted:

STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only.Â  State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, ___ S.C. ___, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004); State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  This Court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000).Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  The appellate court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence, but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence. Mattison, 352 S.C. at 583, 575 S.E.2d at 855.

LAW/ANALYSIS
I.Â  Admissibility of Prior Convictions
Generally, evidence of a defendantâ€™s character is not admissible to show a propensity to act in conformity therewith; however, it is well settled that if a defendant places his character in issue, the State may offer evidence of the defendantâ€™s bad character.Â  See Rule 404(a)(1), SCRE (â€œEvidence of a personâ€™s character or a trait of character is not admissible for the purpose of proving action in conformity therewith on a particular occasion, except: (1) Character of Accused.Â  Evidence of a pertinent trait of character offered by an accused, or by the prosecution to rebut the same[.]â€).
The jurisprudence of this State contains a plethora of enlightening cases establishing and explicating the proposition that a defendant may open the door to what would otherwise be improper evidence.Â  For instance, State v. Allen, 266 S.C. 468, 224 S.E.2d 881 (1976), overruled on other grounds by State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991), although it never uses the open door language, is often cited for the door-opening doctrine.Â  See, e.g., State v. Major, 301 S.C. 181, 391 S.E.2d 235 (1990); State v. Plath, 281 S.C. 1, 313 S.E.2d 619 (1984); State v. Doby, 273 S.C. 704, 258 S.E.2d 896 (1979).Â  In Allen, the defendant, who was accused of kidnapping and murder, offered four good-character witnesses.Â  He then took the stand and described his past criminal activities.Â  The Allen court explained, â€œThe gist of his testimony was to show to the jury that, though he was admittedly an habitual criminal, none of his nefarious acts were committed with the use of force, so as to harm any person.â€Â  266 S.C. at 481, 224 S.E.2d at 886.Â  The court observed:Â  â€œBy presenting character witnesses, defendant placed his good character and general reputation in issue; by submitting evidence of his criminal past, with the admitted purpose of establishing his propensity for nonviolence, defendant placed this specific character trait in issue.â€Â  Id. at 481-82, 224 S.E.2d at 886. 
On cross-examination, the solicitor questioned Allen about his convictions as well as prior acts of misconduct for which he had not been convicted.Â  Allen argued that inquiry into the wrongful acts was error.Â  The court disagreed:

We recognize certain exceptions to the general rule that an accusedâ€™s bad character may not be offered against him by the State.Â  One exception is where the accused takes the stand and thus becomes subject to impeachment, like any other witness.Â  The accused may thus be cross-examined about any of his past transactions tending to affect his credibility.Â  Taylor v. State, 258 S.C. 369, 188 S.E.2d 850 (1972).Â  Secondly, where the accused offers evidence of his good character, thereby putting his reputation in issue, he may be cross-examined on particular acts which manifestly bear reference to the trait of character covered by the charge in the indictment.Â  State v. Gibert, 196 S.C. 306, 13 S.E.2d 451 (1941).
. . . .
Thus, the solicitor had the right to cross-examine the defendant with respect to conduct which reflected on his credibility as a witness and on the specific character trait involved in the crime charged.Â  

Id. at 482-83, 224 S.E.2d at 886.
In State v. Stroman, 281 S.C. 508, 316 S.E.2d 395 (1984), the defendant was convicted of four counts of murder and five counts of kidnapping, as well as safecracking, assault and battery with intent to kill, armed robbery, and contempt of court.Â  On appeal, he challenged the propriety of allowing the State to introduce testimony indicating Stroman had committed prior armed robberies.Â  Frank McDowell, an accomplice in the crimes, testified for the State.Â  On cross-examination, the defense asked McDowell whether he had ever broken into other homes for money.Â  McDowell admitted that he had.Â  On redirect, the State sought to further question McDowell as to two of the incidents in which Stroman had participated as well.Â  Over the defenseâ€™s objection, â€œThe trial judge ruled the â€˜door had been openedâ€™ to inquiry into appellantâ€™s participation in â€˜any crime that included a breaking into a buildingâ€™ or â€˜armed robbery or some stealing of money.â€™â€Â  Id. at 513, 316 S.E.2d at 399.Â  The supreme court agreed: â€œWhere one party introduces evidence as to a particular fact or transaction, the other party is entitled to introduce evidence in explanation or rebuttal thereof, even though [the] latter evidence would be incompetent or irrelevant had it been offered initially.â€Â  Id. (alterations in original) (citing State v. Albert, 277 S.E.2d 439, 441 (N.C. 1981)).Â  The court held:

Once appellantâ€™s counsel initiated the questioning concerning McDowellâ€™s prior acts of theft, the State was free to question him as to the details of any prior crime involving the stealing of money.Â  The scope of redirect rests in the discretion of the trial court.Â  State v. Tyner, 273 S.C. 646, 258 S.E.2d 559 (1979).Â  We hold the trial court properly admitted McDowellâ€™s testimony.

281 S.C. at 513, 316 S.E.2d at 399.
In State v. Doby, 273 S.C. 704, 258 S.E.2d 896 (1979), the defendant was convicted of murder.Â  The State was allowed to elicit evidence of Dobyâ€™s prior convictions for trespassing in womenâ€™s restrooms.Â  The South Carolina Supreme Court employed the open-door doctrine in finding the admission proper:

Appellant next asserts error in allowing the solicitor to cross examine him and his psychiatric witnesses about appellantâ€™s two prior convictions for trespassing in public womenâ€™s restrooms, and in admitting a note he had left in one of those restrooms into evidence.Â  We hold that appellant opened the door to this cross examination by direct testimony regarding his passive character and lack of mature sexual desires. 

Id. at 710, 258 S.E.2d at 899-900 (citations omitted).
State v. Major, 301 S.C. 181, 391 S.E.2d 235 (1990), is an edifying opinion.Â  Major was convicted of distribution of crack cocaine.Â  The trial judge allowed the State to introduce a prior conviction for simple possession of cocaine after Major denied having ever used the drug.Â  The court found that Major had made a â€œclear attempt . . . to communicate to the jury that he [wa]s not the sort of individual who would become involved in the drug trade.â€Â  Therefore, â€œHaving introduced evidence of his own good character on the issue of involvement in drugs, Major thereby became subject to cross-examination on that assertion.â€Â  Id. at 185-86, 391 S.E.2d at 238.Â  
State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 409 S.E.2d 404 (1991), is another demonstration of the supreme courtâ€™s utilization of the door-opening theory.Â  Robinson allegedly hired members of El Rukn, a Chicago-based gang, to murder the victim.Â  The disputed evidence emanated from the solicitorâ€™s questioning Henry Harris, a member of El Rukn.Â  The court explained: â€œHarris testified that in the 1980â€™s he was in charge of drug operations for the organization.Â  He was subsequently asked when he first became acquainted with appellant and he answered â€œâ€™83 or â€™84.â€Â  Id. at 474, 409 S.E.2d at 408.Â  Appellant objected and moved for a mistrial on the ground Harrisâ€™ testimony linked appellant to drug dealing.Â  After finding that the testimony did not imply appellant was involved in drug dealing, the court addressed the open-door doctrine:

Further, appellant was the first to bring out the El Ruknâ€™s involvement in drug dealing.Â  A previous witness, gang member Eugene Hunter, testified appellant was a friend of Jeff Fort, the head of El Rukns, and was assisting the El Rukns in establishing a legitimate business.Â  On cross-examination, appellant elicited testimony from Hunter that El Rukns were involved in drug dealing.Â  Since appellant opened the door to this evidence, he cannot complain of prejudice from its admission.Â  

Id. at 474, 409 S.E.2d at 408 (citation omitted).
State v. Beam, 336 S.C. 45, 518 S.E.2d 297 (Ct. App. 1999), involved a conviction of transfer of recorded sounds for pirating videotapes.Â  The defense questioned expert Beasley whether he had performed a particular type of test, a switch point test, in order to determine the authenticity of allegedly pirated videos.Â  Beasley had not performed the test.Â  The defense then questioned expert Bowley about the switch point test.Â  Although Bowley had not conducted the test, he stated that he could arrange to perform the test in court.Â  Over the defenseâ€™s objection, Bowley was allowed to perform the test on two tapes, both of which he determined were counterfeits.Â  This Court concluded:

Beam cannot complain about the admission of evidence where he opened the door to the evidence.Â  See State v. Robinson, 305 S.C. 469, 409 S.E.2d 404 (1991) (where appellant opened door to evidence, he cannot complain of prejudice from its admission); State v. Sullivan, 277 S.C. 35, 282 S.E.2d 838 (1981) (appellant cannot complain of prejudice from admission of evidence if he opened the door to its admission).Â  Further, when a party introduces evidence about a particular matter, the other party is entitled to explain it or rebut it, even if the latter evidence would have been incompetent or irrelevant had it been offered initially.Â  State v. Stroman, 281 S.C. 508, 316 S.E.2d 395 (1984).Â  A party may not complain of error caused by his own conduct.Â  Id.

336 S.C. at 53, 518 S.E.2d at 301.
In State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 508 S.E.2d 870 (1999), the trial court allowed the State to introduce the defendantâ€™s prior criminal domestic violence convictions due to his opening the door to such evidence.Â  The defendant stipulated he killed his wife by strangling her with a t-shirt.Â  However, he denied the killing was murder.Â  Taylor took the stand and stated that â€œthings had kind of gotten rough for us the last couple of years . . . .â€Â  Id. at 172, 508 S.E.2d at 877.Â  On cross-examination, the State brought out an eight-year-old conviction for criminal domestic violence to rebut Taylorâ€™s assertion that things were rough â€œthe last couple of years.â€ 
Taylor contended the judge erred by allowing the solicitor to impeach him with a prior conviction for criminal domestic violence.Â  The court disagreed and noted:

An â€œaccused may be cross-examined as to all matters which he himself has brought up on direct examination.â€Â  98 C.J.S. Witnesses Â§ 515 at 439 (1957); State v. Allen, 266 S.C. 468, 224 S.E.2d 881 (1976), citing 98 C.J.S. Witnesses Â§ 378 at 134-135 (â€œ[a]s a general rule, any matter is proper subject of cross-examination which is responsive to testimony given on direct examination, or which is material or relevant thereto, and which tends to elucidate, modify, explain, contradict or rebut testimony given in chief by the witness.â€). The cross-examination of matters which were addressed in direct-examination is not objectionable, even if the answers affect a witness' credibility and character.Â  98 C.J.S. Witnesses Â§ 378.

Â  Id. at 174-75, 508 S.E.2d at 878 (footnote omitted).
Further, the Taylor court found:

[T]his testimony did not place appellantâ€™s character in issue.Â  However, because appellant â€œopened the doorâ€ about his relationship with his wife, the solicitor was entitled to cross-examine him about the relationship, even if the responses brought out appellantâ€™s prior criminal domestic violence conviction.Â  

Id. at 175, 508 S.E.2d at 878 (footnote and citations omitted).
The doctrine of opening the door was used by this Court in State v. Knighton, 334 S.C. 125, 512 S.E.2d 117 (Ct. App. 1999).Â  Knighton was arrested and convicted for driving under the influence.Â Â  Knighton testified on direct examination that Charleston and Greenville law enforcement made videotaping tests available to DUI arrestees, whereas his request for a videotape from Orangeburg was refused because they lacked the equipment.Â  The solicitor questioned Knighton on how he knew the other counties used video equipment.Â  The trial judge instructed the witness not to answer the question, and Knighton moved for a mistrial.Â  The court held: 

Though there was the potential for prejudicial testimony to have been submitted to the jury, the trial judge prevented any prejudice by instructing Knighton not to answer the solicitorâ€™s question. Further, appellant himself opened the door to this inference by testifying about his knowledge of videotaping offered to DUI suspects in two other counties.Â  Accordingly, we find no abuse of discretion.

Id. at 134, 512 S.E.2d at 112. 
In State v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 579 S.E.2d 318 (2003), Dunlap was convicted for distribution of crack cocaine.Â  During opening statements, counsel for Dunlap professed that the defendant had â€œbeen in trouble with the lawâ€ and was â€œhooked on crack and had a problem with it,â€ but â€œnever sold it.â€Â  Id. at 541, 579 S.E.2d at 319.Â  Based on these statements, the State was able to introduce Dunlapâ€™s prior convictions for conspiracy to possess crack cocaine with intent to distribute; distribution of an imitation drug; simple possession of marijuana; and shoplifting.Â  The Dunlap court explicated:

The opening statement created the impression that petitioner had no prior connection to the sale of narcotics.Â  In reality, petitioner was not a mere drug user, but an individual who sought to â€˜elevateâ€™ his status to that of a drug dealer. . . .Â  We therefore agree . . . that petitionerâ€™s counsel opened the door to the introduction of evidence rebutting the contention that petitioner was merely an addict.

Id. at 541, 579 S.E.2d at 319 (citations omitted).
Moreover, the court found an analysis under Rule 609, SCRE, unnecessary:

Because we find that counsel opened the door to the admission of petitionerâ€™s prior drug record, we need not reach the issue whether these convictions were admissible to impeach petitionerâ€™s credibility under Rule 609, [SCRE]. 

Id. at 542, 579 S.E.2d at 320.
In the case of State v. Curtis, 356 S.C. 622, 591 S.E.2d 600 (2004), Curtis was convicted of two counts of the sale of urine with the intent to defraud a drug or alcohol test.Â  At trial, both Curtis and his webmaster testified that Curtisâ€™s website did not contain pornographic material, or links to websites containing pornographic material.Â  On cross-examination, the State questioned Curtis about pornographic links and demonstrated, in court, how pornography indirectly could be accessed through links on pages linked to Curtisâ€™s page.Â  Curtis argued that this inquiry was irrelevant and misleading.Â  However, the court held:Â  â€œGiven that both Curtis and Turner maintained that PPS did not allow pornographic materials or links on the website, it is patent that they opened the door to this line of inquiry.â€Â  Id. at 632, 591 S.E.2d at 605 (citation omitted).Â  
State v. McIntosh, 358 S.C. 432, 595 S.E.2d 484 (2004), discusses the door-opening doctrine in the context of a Doyle violation, ultimately concluding the doctrine did not apply to the facts of McIntosh.Â  At issue was the solicitorâ€™s questioning the defendant â€œat length about his failure to present his alibi defense to police after he was arrested and given the Miranda warnings.â€Â  Id. at 444, 595 S.E.2d at 490.Â  The court observed:

The State correctly explains other courts have held a defendant may open the door to cross-examination for impeachment purposes by testifying or creating the impression through his defense presentation he has cooperated with police when, in fact, he has not.Â  Such cross-examination is permissible, as the Supreme Court recognized in Doyle by noting a prosecutor may challenge a defendantâ€™s contention he told his exculpatory story to police when he actually did not.

358 S.C. at 445, 595 S.E.2d at 491 (citations omitted).Â  However, the court found that McIntosh â€œdid not open the door to any Doyle violationâ€ because he â€œdid not, explicitly or implicitly, assert he cooperated with police.â€Â  Id.  
State v. White, 361 S.C. 407, 605 S.E.2d 540 (2004), involves a defendant convicted of first-degree criminal sexual conduct and kidnapping.Â  At trial, Cole Badger, a psychotherapist who counseled the victim and was qualified as an expert, testified for the State.Â  White argued that Badger was improperly allowed to testify that she believed the victim.Â  The court concluded, â€œWhite opened the door to this testimony by cross-examining Badger as to whether she had cases in which she did not believe the alleged victim.Â  State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (2003) (one who opens the door to evidence cannot complain of its admission).â€Â  White at 415-16; 605 S.E.2d at 544.Â  
A number of additional arbitraments are extant wherein South Carolina courts have addressed the door-opening doctrine.Â  See State v. Foster, 354 S.C. 614, 582 S.E.2d 426 (2003) (finding Rule 801(d)(1)(B), SCRE is the sole means by which a prior consistent statement may be introduced and therefore, the Stateâ€™s argument that defendant opened the door to the prior consistent statement, while it may have been proper under pre-SCRE law, is simply not tenable under the SCRE); State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 493 S.E.2d 845 (1997) (determining testimony that witness gave defendant drugs proper to rebut prior witnessâ€™s testimony that implied defendant was adamantly opposed to drugs); State v. Sullivan, 277 S.C. 35, 45, 282 S.E.2d 838, 844 (1981) (holding where â€œ[d]efense counsel asked Agent Powell on cross-examination whether the plastic was common place [sic] or specially made[, the] question opened the door for Powellâ€™s response that it was used inside the aircraft to set bales of marijuana on.â€); State v. Plath, 281 S.C. 1, 7, 313 S.E. 2d 619, 623 (1984) (finding no abuse of discretion where defense offered testimony of an expert who disclosed defendantâ€™s juvenile offenses whereupon the State inquired into defendantâ€™s adult offenses and escape; the defense, while objecting to the inquiry, admitted that â€œthe â€˜doorâ€™ had been â€˜openedâ€™â€ to the testimony); State v. Bell, 263 S.C. 239,Â  209 S.E.2d 890 (1974) (ruling that evidence that victim had reported her watch as stolen was proper where defendant averred the victim had given the watch to him); State v. Spinks, 260 S.C. 404, 407-08, 196 S.E.2d 313, 315 (1973) (â€œThe appellant in answer to the question of his counsel, â€˜What chargeâ€™, introduced into record the testimony regarding the prior crimes for which he was sentenced, and in so doing, â€˜opened the doorâ€™ to all crimes for which he was incarcerated, including the crime of carrying a concealed weapon.â€); State v. Kennedy, 143 S.C. 318, 141 S.E. 755 (1928) (finding the trial court properly permitted the State to question victim on the details of previous difficulties victim had with defendant where defendant had first questioned the victim on the details of the prior difficulties); State v. Bramlett, 114 S.C. 389, 103 S.E. 755 (1920) (ruling the State may offer rebutting evidence of the defendantâ€™s familyâ€™s reputation for insanity where defendant offers evidence of his familyâ€™s reputation for insanity); State v. Marks, 70 S.C. 448, 50 S.E. 14 (1905) (mentioning the opening the door theory); State v. Trotter, 317 S.C. 411, 415, 453 S.E.2d 905, 908 (Ct. App. 1997) (citing Benton & Rhodes, Inc. v. Boden, 310 S.C. 400, 426 S.E.2d 823 (Ct. App. 1993) for the proposition that â€œthere is no error in admitting evidence where the appellant opened the door to the evidenceâ€) affâ€™d as modified by State v. Trotter, 322 S.C. 537, 473 S.E.2d 452 (1996). 
Adverting to the case sub judice, Youngâ€™s testimony is replete with statements that connote character traits antithetical to the character evinced by his prior convictions of criminal domestic violence and criminal sexual conduct.Â  Most poignant is his statement: â€œlike I told my lawyer, I hate to see a female cry.â€Â  Yet the denouement of this case need not hang on the lone phrase â€œI hate to see a female cryâ€; throughout his testimony, Young characterized himself as a benefactor and protector of women generally and of the victim particularly.Â  His testimony demonstrates a concerted attempt to paint himself as a gallant man with the victimâ€™s best interest and safety always on his mind.Â  
Young testified he told the other drug dealers, â€œI donâ€™t want nobody bothering her,â€ and he told the victim to â€œlock your windows . . . . Donâ€™t talk to nobody.â€Â  He expanded his expressions of concern for the victim to all women when he asseverated: â€œI hate to see a female cry.â€Â  In addition to these physical and emotional concerns, Young related disquietude over the victimâ€™s chastity, saying she should not have to â€œbelittleâ€ herself, and telling her he would be â€œjust as wrong if I allowed myself to let you go through this right here [perform sexual favors on him].â€
Because Young set before the jury his concern for the victimâ€™s safety and chastity, the State was entitled to rebut his assertions with evidence of his prior abuse and the criminal results of his concupiscence.Â  Young opened the door to the convictions for criminal domestic violence and criminal sexual conduct.Â Â Â  
II.Â  Racially Biased Comments
Young claims the trial court erred in allowing the solicitor to ask Young racially inflammatory questions.Â  During cross-examination of Young, the State asked, â€œMr. Young, isnâ€™t it also true that you like going out and being with white women?â€Â  Young admitted that he has a child with a Caucasian woman.Â  The State then asked Young if he â€œprefer[ed] being with white women.â€Â  
We find this argument is not preserved for our review.Â  The lack of a contemporaneous objection to an improper argument acts as a wavier, except where a â€œvicious, inflammatory argument results in clear prejudice.â€Â  Toyota of Florence, Inc. v. Lynch, 314 S.C. 257, 263, 442 S.E.2d 611, 615 (1994).Â  While the Toyota court did not condone a failure to make a contemporaneous objection, it found it â€œwholly unreasonable for any attorney to anticipateâ€ flagrant, abhorrent conduct towards a party or witness.Â  Id.Â  However, the issue must be raised to the trial court by way of a post-trial motion.Â  Dial v. Niggel Assoc., Inc., 333 S.C. 253, 257, 509 S.E.2d 269, 271 (1998).Â  Because Young did not make a contemporaneous objection and did not present the issue during a post-trial motion, this issue is not preserved.Â  
CONCLUSION
Based on the foregoing, Youngâ€™s convictions are
 AFFIRMED.
STILWELL, J., concurs.
SHORT, J., dissents in a separate opinion.Â  
SHORT, J., dissenting:Â  I respectfully dissent regarding the issue of whether the trial court erred in admitting Youngâ€™s prior convictions for criminal sexual conduct and criminal domestic violence.
In a criminal case, the State cannot attack the defendantâ€™s character unless the defendant first places his or her own character in issue.Â  State v. Taylor, 333 S.C. 159, 174, 508 S.E.2d 870, 877-878 (1998).Â  â€œWhen the accused offers evidence of his good character regarding specific character traits relevant to the crime charged, the solicitor has the right to cross-examine him as to particular bad acts or conduct.â€Â  State v. Major, 301 S.C. 181, 185, 391 S.E.2d 235, 238 (1990).Â  However, the State is restricted to showing bad character only for the traits initially focused on by the accused.Â  Id.Â  Also, â€œwhere prior convictions or misconduct are appropriately brought out on cross-examination, the State may inquire only so far as to bring out the nature of the conviction or activity and may not go into details.â€Â  State v. Allen, 266 S.C. 468, 482, 224 S.E.2d 881, 886 (1976), overruled on other grounds by State v. Evans, 307 S.C. 477, 415 S.E.2d 816 (1992), and State v. Torrence, 305 S.C. 45, 406 S.E.2d 315 (1991).
When the prior crime is similar to the one for which the defendant is being tried, the danger of unfair prejudice to the defendant from impeachment by that prior offense weighs against its admission.Â  State v. Dunlap, 353 S.C. 539, 542, 579 S.E.2d 318, 320 (2003).Â  Thus, the trial court must consider the impeachment value of the prior crime, the timing of the prior crime, the similarity between the past crime and the charged crime, the importance of the defendantâ€™s testimony, and the centrality of the credibility issue.Â  Green v. State, 338 S.C. 428, 433-34, 527 S.E.2d 98, 101 (2000).Â  In determining whether similar prior convictions can be used to impeach the accused, the trial court must weigh the probative value of the prior convictions against their prejudicial effect to the accused and determine, in its discretion, whether to admit the evidence.Â  Id.; Rule 609(a)(1), SCRE.
During an in camera hearing, the trial judge ruled the probative value of admitting Youngâ€™s previous conviction for criminal sexual conduct was outweighed by its prejudicial value and allowed the prosecution to proceed by stating only that there was another felony for which Young had been convicted.Â  The prosecution did not raise Youngâ€™s prior conviction for criminal domestic violence to the judge during the hearing, so the judge did not rule on its admission.Â  After his direct examination, the State argued that Young had placed his character in issue with his statements insinuating that he was concerned about the victimâ€™s well-being, particularly in the following testimony:

Â . . . and thatâ€™s when she said, I need to talk to you about something.Â  She said, I ainâ€™t ready to go.Â  Not yet.Â  I said, okay. Â Whatâ€™s up?Â  So she like start crying.Â  So I said [victimâ€™s name], look, I ainâ€™t angry no more.Â  Because, see, like I told my lawyer, I hate to see a female cry.Â  So I said, all right.Â  I ainâ€™t angry no more.Â  I ainâ€™t angry no more.Â  Itâ€™s all good.Â  I ainâ€™t angry no more. 

(emphasis added).Â  The State further contended that Young placed his character in issue by testifying that he was angry at the victim because â€œshe donâ€™t have to belittle herself like thatâ€ by performing oral sex on the other drug dealer and by testifying that he told her he was â€œgoing to make sure [she was] all right.â€Â  The trial judge determined that Youngâ€™s testimony had opened the door by injecting a character trait in issue and allowed the State to impeach the defendant with his prior criminal convictions for a 1994 criminal sexual conduct 3rd degree and a 1993 criminal domestic violence. 
After carefully reviewing Youngâ€™s testimony, I find he did not place his character in issue and, therefore, did not open the door for admitting into evidence his prior convictions for criminal sexual conduct 3rd degree and criminal domestic violence.Â  Young testified he sold drugs to the victim; however, he denied kidnapping or criminally assaulting her.Â  Youngâ€™s testimony, when considered in proper context, did not connote specific character traits toward his treatment of females, but rather described and explained his version of what transpired between the victim and himself on the night in question.
I now address the question of whether the error was harmless, which necessarily depends on the particular circumstances of any case.Â  â€œError is harmless when it could not reasonably have affected the result of the trial.â€Â  State v. Reeves, 301 S.C. 191, 194, 391 S.E.2d 241, 243 (1990).Â  â€œError which substantially damages the defendantâ€™s credibility cannot be held harmless where such credibility is essential to his defense.â€Â  Id.Â  Young was on trial for criminal sexual conduct 1st degree and kidnapping.Â  The trial jury could have concluded that Young had a greater propensity to commit a crime of a sexual nature because of his prior convictions for criminal sexual conduct 3rd degree and criminal domestic violence.Â  Id.Â  Whether Young committed the offenses of criminal sexual conduct 1st degree and kidnapping in this case essentially boils down to the conflicting testimony of the victim and Young himself.Â  Because of the credibility issue in this case, the erroneous admission of Youngâ€™s prior convictions for similar offenses cannot be found to be harmless error, and, therefore, I would reverse and remand Youngâ€™s conviction for criminal sexual conduct 1st degree and kidnapping.

title: Martasin v. Hilton Head Health System
description: This is an appeal of a directed verdict for the defendants in a medical malpractice action.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
        Donna C. Martasin, Personal Representative of the Estate of Edwin S.
        Martasin, Deceased, for the benefit of the heirs at law, Donna C.
        Martasin, Kenneth E. Martasin, and Jerald A. Martasin, Appellants,
v.
Hilton Head Health System, L.P.; Amisub (Hilton Head), Inc.; Tenet Physician Services, Hilton Head, Inc.; Hilton Head Health System, L.P., Amisub (Hilton Head), Inc., Tenet Physician Services Hilton Head, Inc., d/b/a Hilton Head Medical Center & Clinics; Urgent Care Center of Hilton Head Medical Center & Clinics; Gerald E.
Vanderpool, M.D.; Christina S. Gwozdz, M.D.; Paul M.Â  Long, M.D.; Frank L. Hart, M.D.; Kenneth C.
Kunze, M.D.; Gary W. Thomas, M.D.; Charles T. Lucas, M.D., Defendants, Of Whom Hilton Head Health System, L.P., Tenet Physician Services Hilton Head, Inc., d/b/a Hilton Head Medical Center & Clinics; Urgent Care Center of Hilton Head Medical Center & Clinics; Paul M.Â  Long, M.D.; Frank L. Hart, M.D.; and Gary W. Thomas, M.D. are the,
Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Beaufort County
Â Jackson V. Gregory, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3984
Heard January 13, 2005 â€“ Filed May 2, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
H. Fred Kuhn, Jr., of Beaufort, for Appellant.
E. Douglas Pratt-Thomas, Francis M. Ervin, II, J. Rutledge Young, Jr., Stephen L. Brown, John K. Blincow, Jr., R. Gerald Chambers, Jr., Robert H. Hood, Robert H. Hood, Jr., and Deborah H. Sheffield, all of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

KITTREDGE, J.:Â  Donna C. Martasin (Mrs. Martasin) brought wrongful death and conscious pain and suffering claims against three physicians (and related corporate health care entities), alleging they committed medical malpractice in negligently failing to treat and prevent the fatal side effects of a cancer treatment administered to her husband, Edwin S. Martasin (Mr. Martasin).Â  At trial, the circuit court entered a directed verdict in favor of all the defendants on the grounds Mrs. Martasin failed to present sufficient evidence to prove to a reasonable degree of medical certainty that the alleged negligence â€œmost probablyâ€ caused her husbandâ€™s deathâ€”the required burden of proof in such medical malpractice cases.Â  We affirm the directed verdict as to Defendant Dr. Frank L. Hart and reverse with respect to Defendants Dr. Paul M. Long and Dr. Gary W. Thomas.Â  Additionally, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict on Mrs. Martasinâ€™s claim for punitive damages.
FACTS/PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Mr. Martasinâ€™s Disease and Medical Treatment
This appeal concerns the medical treatment Mr. Martasin received from the three defendant physicians (respondents here) during the time immediately after he was initially diagnosed with a form of blood cancer leukemia.Â  The relevant undisputed facts are as follows.
On Monday, December 4, 1995, Mr. Martasin sought treatment at the emergency room of Hilton Head Hospital for persistent headaches, fever, and fatigue.Â  Mr. Martasin was examined by Dr. Paul Long, an internal medicine specialist.Â  After his initial examination, Dr. Long decided to admit Mr. Martasin to the hospital for further tests.Â  Based on the initial test results, Dr. Long suspected Mr. Martasin had some form of the blood cancer leukemia.Â  Dr. Long called in Dr. Gary Thomas, an oncologist, for consultation.Â  Dr. Thomas examined Mr. Martasin and performed additional tests.Â  Dr. Thomas concluded that Mr. Martasinâ€™s clinical presentation was consistent with leukemia.Â  The doctors ordered more sophisticated blood tests to confirm the diagnosis. 
On Thursday, December 7, 1995, Dr. Thomas determined that Mr. Martasin should immediately begin a course of treatment to counteract the effects of the cancer.Â  Mr. Martasin was given a prescription for the drug Prednisone to be taken daily. Later that day, he was discharged from the hospital with instructions to return to see Dr. Thomas the following Monday, December 11th.Â  Mr. Martasin left the hospital, filled the prescription for the Prednisone, and took the medication as instructed. 
While Mr. Martasin was at home, the doctors arranged for a home health care nurse to check in on him each day.Â  When the nurse visited on Saturday, December 9th, Mr. Martasinâ€™s condition had noticeably worsened.Â  The nurse paged Dr. Long, who responded by telephone, speaking directly with Mrs. Martasin.Â  Dr. Long declined to see Mr. Martasin that day, but he instructed Mrs. Martasin to take her husband back to the emergency room where Dr. Frank Hart, Dr. Longâ€™s medical practice associate, would meet them.Â  At the hospital, Dr. Hart examined Mr. Martasin and performed blood, urine and other tests.Â  Dr. Hart informed Mr. Martasin that the examination and laboratory test results did not indicate a change in his condition that would warrant readmitting him to the hospital.Â  Dr. Hart instructed the Martasins to return home and to keep their appointment with Dr. Thomas scheduled for the following Monday. 
When Mr. Martasin returned for his Monday appointment, Dr. Thomas found his condition had deteriorated substantially since his initial discharge from the hospital.Â  That evening, Mr. Martasin was transferred to the Intensive Care Unit at the Medical University of South Carolina, where he lapsed into unconsciousness and died the next morning, December 12. 
Dr. Lawrence Afrin, an oncologist at MUSC who examined Mr. Martasin, concluded Mr. Martasin was suffering from a condition known as â€œTumor Lysis Syndromeâ€ (TLS) when he arrived at MUSC.Â Â  Furthermore, the pathologist who performed the autopsy on Mr. Martasin reported that her findings as to the cause of death were clinically consistent with TLS.Â  
As described in the undisputed portions of the medical testimony, TLS is a serious, yet predictable, complication that arises when treating cancer with certain medications.Â  Treatments such as Prednisone work to attack the cancer cells in the body.Â  As the dead cells are broken down by the body, the chemicals in the cells are released into the bloodstream.Â  TLS occurs when these chemical by-products are released in quantities that overwhelm the bodyâ€™s ability to restore the proper chemical balance in the blood.Â  If a patient is at risk of TLS, the treating physician can prescribe certain prophylactic measures that will flush out the harmful chemicals in the bloodstream and aid the body in regulating the chemical balance in the blood.Â  Failure to properly institute these prophylactic measures can lead to the death of a patient suffering from TLS. 
This Action
As personal representative of her husbandâ€™s estate, Mrs. Martasin filed suit against Dr. Long, Dr. Thomas, and Dr. Hart, as well as the physiciansâ€™ medical practices, alleging they were negligent in failing to treat and prevent the side effects of Mr. Martasinâ€™s TLS.Â  At trial, Mrs. Martasin offered expert testimony to establish the negligence of these physicians proximately caused the death of her husband.Â  At the close of the evidence, all three doctors moved for a directed verdict claiming the expert testimony failed to establish that the alleged deviation from the standard of care proximately caused Mr. Martasinâ€™s death to â€œa reasonable degree of medical certainty.â€Â  The circuit court granted the motion for directed verdict with respect to all three doctors and the corresponding corporate defendants, finding Mrs. Martasin did not establish the conduct of the doctors â€œmost probablyâ€ resulted in the death of Edwin Martasin.Â  Also, the circuit court directed a verdict denying Mrs. Martasinâ€™s claim for punitive damages.Â  This appeal followed.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
When ruling on a motion for directed verdict, the court must view the evidence and the inferences that can reasonably be drawn therefrom in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Sabb v. South Carolina State Univ., 350 S.C. 416, 427, 567 S.E.2d 231, 236 (2002).Â  If the evidence as a whole is susceptible of more than one reasonable inference, a jury issue is created and the motion should be denied.Â  Adams v. G.J. Creel & Sons, Inc., 320 S.C. 274, 277, 465 S.E.2d 84, 85 (1995); Bailey v. Segars, 346 S.C. 359, 365-66, 550 S.E.2d 910, 913 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  However, this rule does not authorize submission of speculative, theoretical, and hypothetical views to the jury.Â  Hanahan v. Simpson, 326 S.C. 140, 149, 485 S.E.2d 903, 908 (1997).
LAW/ANALYSIS
I. Directed Verdict On Negligence Claims
The primary issue in this appeal is whether Mrs. Martasin presented sufficient evidence to establish the defendant physicians breached the applicable standard of care and that breach proximately caused her husbandâ€™s death.Â  To prove these critical components of her negligence claim, Mrs. Martasin relied on the testimony of medical experts, particularly the testimony of Dr. Mansoor N. Saleh.Â  After careful review of the evidentiary record, especially Dr. Salehâ€™s testimony, we find there is sufficient evidence for a reasonable jury to conclude the alleged acts of Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas in treating Mr. Martasin deviated from the standard of care and were a proximate cause of the death of Mr. Martasin.Â  The directed verdict granted in favor of these two physicians, therefore, should not have been granted.Â  We reach a different conclusion with regard to Dr. Hart.Â  Viewing the evidence as a whole, we are unable to find sufficient evidence to establish any act or omission by Dr. Hart proximately caused Mr. Martasinâ€™s death.Â  The directed verdict in favor of Dr. Hart shall, therefore, stand. 
A plaintiff in a medical malpractice case must establish by expert testimony both the standard of care and the defendantâ€™s failure to conform to the required standard, unless the subject matter is of common knowledge or experience so that no special learning is needed to evaluate the defendantâ€™s conduct. Gooding v. St. Francis Xavier Hosp., 326 S.C. 248, 254, 487 S.E.2d 596, 599 (1997).Â  â€œIn addition to proving the defendant negligent, the plaintiff must also prove that the defendantâ€™s negligence was a proximate cause of the plaintiffâ€™s injury.â€ Carver v. Med. Socâ€™y of S.C., 286 S.C. 347, 350, 334 S.E.2d 125, 127 (Ct. App. 1985).Â  Our supreme court has articulated the burden of proof borne by plaintiffs in proving proximate cause in medical malpractice cases:

Negligence is not actionable unless it is a proximate cause of the injury complained of, and negligence may be deemed a proximate cause only when without such negligence the injury would not have occurred or could have been avoided.Â  When one relies solely upon the opinion of medical experts to establish a causal connection between the alleged negligence and the injury, the experts must, with reasonable certainty, state that in their professional opinion, the injuries complained of most probably resulted from the defendantâ€™s negligence.Â  The reason for this rule is the highly technical nature of malpractice litigation.Â  Since many malpractice suits involve ailments and treatments outside the realm of ordinary lay knowledge, expert testimony is generally necessary.Â  

Ellis v. Oliver, 323 S.C. 121, 125, 473 S.E.2d 793, 795 (1996) (citations omitted and emphasis added).Â  Therefore, the expert testimony as to proximate cause must provide a significant causal link between the alleged negligence and the injuries suffered, rather than a tenuous and hypothetical connection.Â  Id.
However, in determining whether particular evidence meets the â€œmost probablyâ€ test, it is not necessary that the testifying expert actually use the words â€œmost probably.â€Â  Baughman v. Am. Tel. & Tel., 306 S.C. 101, 111, 410 S.E.2d 537, 543 (1991); see also Gamble v. Price, 289 S.C. 538, 544, 347 S.E.2d 131, 132-33 (Ct. App. 1986) (holding the exact words â€œmost probablyâ€ need not be used by the expert).Â  The Baughman court held:

It is not sufficient for the expert to testify merely that the ailment might or could have resulted from the alleged cause.Â  He must go further and testify that taking into consideration all the data it is his professional opinion that the result in question most probably came from the cause alleged.Â  In determining whether particular evidence meets this test it is not necessary that the expert actually use the words â€œmost probably.â€Â  It is sufficient that the testimony is such â€œas to judicially impress that the opinion . . . represents his professional judgment as to the most likely one among the possible causes.â€

Baughman, 306 S.C. at 111, 410 S.E.2d at 543 (citations omitted).
A.Â  Â Â Â  Alleged Negligence of Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas
Mrs. Martasin relied primarily on the testimony of Dr. Saleh to establish the failure of Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas to treat the TLS was a breach of the standard of care that resulted in the death of Mr. Martasin.Â  
Dr. Saleh testified it was a deviation from the standard of care not to prophylax Mr. Martasin against TLS when administering Prednisone as treatment for leukemia.Â  Dr. Saleh testified:

It is a written law of oncology that any tumor that is sensitive to chemotherapy, there is a propensity of killing the cell very rapidly, that you have to prophylax the patient against the effect of killing the tumor . . . [t]hat kills the malignant cells but the product of cell death results in liver shutdown, kidney shutdown, heart failure . . . . If you treat the patient for that condition, with this amount of tumor burden, you have to prophylax the patient.

Dr. Saleh emphasized the need to take prophylactic measures against the build-up of toxins when you prescribe a patient Prednisone, and, importantly, testified this would be the standard of care for an oncologist as well as a doctor practicing â€œgeneral internal medicine.â€ [1]Â Â  Dr. Saleh explained:

[T]umor lysis prophylaxis is instituted by my residents, first year residents, even by medical students.Â  This is internal medicine therapy.Â  It does not require an oncologist.Â  The oncologist may treat the patient for the treatment of the malignancy but tumor lysis prophylaxis . . . is general internal medicine.Â  In fact, there are board questions that ask internists to say what would you do in a patient getting leukemic therapy for his high white count; you have a high white count, what would you do.Â  And the answer is tumor lysis prophylax.Â  

Based on his review of the pertinent medical records, Dr. Saleh concluded that the cause of Mr. Martasinâ€™s death was the TLS that occurred as a result of the Prednisone being administered without necessary prophylactic measures being instituted. Admittedly, Dr. Saleh did not use the magic words â€œmost probably,â€ but the entirety of the evidence persuades us that Mrs. Martasin presented sufficient evidence to withstand the directed verdict motion with respect to Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas.Â Â Â  
Accordingly, viewing the evidence in the light most favorable to Mrs. Martasin as we must, we conclude that a reasonable jury could have found as fact that Mr. Martasinâ€™s death was most probably the result of the Prednisone treatment that Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas implemented without taking appropriate measures to treat the TLS.Â  The order of the circuit court granting a directed verdict in favor of these two physicians is reversed, and the matter is remanded for a new trial.Â  Additionally, our ruling reversing the directed verdict as to these two individual defendants extends to the corresponding corporate defendants plaintiff claimed were vicariously liable for Dr. Longâ€™s and Dr. Thomasâ€™s alleged negligence.
B.Â Â Â Â Â  Proof of Causal Link to the Alleged Negligence of Dr. Hart
As noted above, Dr. Frank Hart was the physician who examined Mr. Martasin when he returned to Hilton Head Hospital on Saturday, December 9th, after the initial discharge by Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas two days earlier.Â  Dr. Hart concluded it was not necessary to admit Mr. Martisan to the hospital at that time.Â  Mrs. Martasin claims there is sufficient evidence upon which a reasonable jury could conclude the failure of Dr. Hart to admit her husband to the hospital that Saturday and implement prophylaxis for the TLS was a proximate cause of her husbandâ€™s death.Â  We disagree.Â  
Plaintiffâ€™s expert, Dr. Saleh, was asked about Dr. Hartâ€™s examination of Mr. Martasin on Saturday, December 9th and whether Mr. Martasinâ€™s death could have been prevented had Dr. Hart admitted him to the hospital that day and begun immediate prophylactic measures to counteract the TLS.Â  Though the transcript reveals some confusion in Dr. Salehâ€™s initial attempt to respond to this line of questioning, defense counsel asked for and received clarification:

DR. SALEH: . . . If you have not prophylaxed and you get into the acute setting, the odds are less.Â  But thereâ€™s still one in three chance you can salvage the patient in that setting, yes.Â  

Therefore, according to Dr. Salehâ€™s expert opinion, there was only a â€œone in three chanceâ€ Mr. Martasinâ€™s fatal TLS could have been prevented had Dr. Hart admitted Mr. Martasin on Saturday, December 9th and initiated immediate prophylactic measures.Â  This assessment fails to establish the causal link required under South Carolina law to recover for medical negligence.
We first note that our supreme court has expressly declined to adopt the â€œloss of chanceâ€ doctrine, which, in the context of medical malpractice, â€œpermits a recovery when the delay in proper diagnosis or treatment of a medical condition results in the patient being deprived of a less than even chance of surviving or recovering.â€Â  Jones v. Owings, 318 S.C. 72, 75, 456 S.E.2d 371, 373 (1995).Â  In rejecting the doctrine, the supreme court stated, â€œWe consider the better rule to be that in order to comport with the standard of proof of proximate cause, plaintiff in a malpractice case must prove that defendantâ€™s negligence, in probability, proximately caused the death.â€ Id. at 76, 456 S.E.2d at 373 (emphasis in original).
More recently, in Haselden v. Davis, 341 S.C. 486, 534 S.E.2d 295 (Ct. App. 2000), this court had the opportunity to determine whether evidence which demonstrates the negligence of a physician in failing to diagnose the decedent, who would have had a greater than fifty percent chance of survival except for the negligence of the doctor, satisfies the â€œmost probablyâ€ standard.Â  We held that, when an individual would have had a greater than fifty percent chance of survival if the physician had properly advised the decedent at an earlier time, evidence of the failure to do so satisfies the â€œmost probablyâ€ requirement for causation. Id. at 495, 534 S.E.2d at 300.
In the instant case, Dr. Salehâ€™s testimony demonstrates that Mr. Martasin would not have had a greater than fifty percent chance of survival if the TLS had been recognized and treated on December 9, 1995.Â  Indeed, the testimony makes plainâ€”in clear, quantitative termsâ€”that Dr. Hartâ€™s decision not to admit Mr. Martasin to the hospital deprived him of roughly a thirty percent chance of survival.Â  The survival chances articulated in this expert assessment therefore fall well short of satisfying the â€œmost probablyâ€ causation standard.Â  Moreover, a thorough review of the record reveals no other evidence that would tend to establish that Dr. Hartâ€™s actions contributed in any material way to Mr. Martasinâ€™s death.Â  
Finding no evidence upon which a reasonable jury could conclude the alleged negligent acts or omissions of Dr. Hart proximately caused Mr. Martasinâ€™s death, we conclude the circuit courtâ€™s grant of a directed verdict in favor of Dr. Hart was proper.Â  Our ruling extends as well to any of the corporate defendants Mrs. Martasin claimed were vicariously liable for Dr. Hartâ€™s alleged negligence.
II. Punitive Damages
Mrs. Martasin argues the circuit court erred in granting Respondentsâ€™ motion for directed verdict on her claim for punitive damages.Â  We agree.
In any civil action where punitive damages are claimed, the plaintiff has the burden of proving such damages by clear and convincing evidence. S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 15-33-135 (2005). Punitive damages can only be awarded where the plaintiff proves by clear and convincing evidence the defendantâ€™s misconduct was willful, wanton, or in reckless disregard of the plaintiffâ€™s rights. Taylor v. Medenica, 324 S.C. 200, 221, 479 S.E.2d 35, 46 (1996); Lister v. NationsBank of Delaware, 329 S.C. 133, 149, 494 S.E.2d 449, 458 (Ct. App. 1997). â€œThe issue of punitive damages must be submitted to the jury if more than one reasonable inference can be drawn from the evidence as to whether the defendantâ€™s behavior was reckless, willful, or wanton.â€ Welch v. Epstein, 342 S.C. 279, 301, 536 S.E.2d 408, 419 (Ct. App. 2000).
Without repeating the relevant testimony already discussed above, and viewing the evidence in a light most favorable to Mrs. Martasin, there is some evidence that the decision by Dr. Long and Dr. Thomas to prescribe Prednisone without instituting prophylactic measures to prevent the TLS was a breach of the most basic standard of care such as to give rise to a reasonable inference that this decision rose to the level of recklessness.Â  Therefore, the issue as to whether these alleged negligent acts were reckless was properly a question for the jury.
CONCLUSION
We find there was sufficient evidence upon which a reasonable jury could conclude that Dr. Longâ€™s and Dr. Thomasâ€™s failure to treat the TLS was a breach of the applicable standard of care that proximately caused Mr. Martasinâ€™s death.Â  We therefore reverse the directed verdict granted in favor of these two defendants and the corresponding corporate entities.Â  With respect to Dr. Hart, we find there was not sufficient evidence proving his alleged negligence proximately caused Mr. Martasinâ€™s death.Â  The directed verdict granted to him and the corresponding corporate defendants is therefore affirmed.Â  Finally, we reverse the circuit courtâ€™s grant of directed verdict on Mrs. Martasinâ€™s claim for punitive damages.Â  
AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.
 HUFF and BEATTY, JJ., concur.

[1]  In granting the directed verdict, the circuit court noted that Dr. Salehâ€™s expert testimony was deficient because he failed to differentiate between the appropriate standard of care applicable to an oncologist (such as Dr. Thomas) versus the standard applicable to a physician who does not specialize in cancer treatment (such as Dr. Long).Â  This distinction, however, is not germane in the present case in light of Dr. Salehâ€™s testimony that the need to prophylax against TLS is basic medical knowledge, known to physicians practicing general internal medicine as well as oncologistsâ€”even â€œfirst year residentsâ€ and â€œmedical students.â€

title: Brewer v. Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc.
description: This appeal arises after summary judgment was granted to a car dealership in a claim for breach of contract, conversion, and violation of certain consumer protection laws brought by a purchaser whose car had been repossessed in what was alleged to have been a yo-yo sale.
text:
Brewer v. Stokes Kia


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Rebecca Brewer, Appellant,
v.
Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc., Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Â A. Victor Rawl, Circuit Court Judge
Â Gerald C. Smoak, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No.Â  3985
Heard March 9, 2005 â€“ Filed May 2, 2005

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Costa Steven Moskos, of Charleston, for Appellant.
Susan Corner Rosen, of Charleston, for Respondent.
      
    
  

HEARN, C.J.: This appeal arises after summary judgment was granted to Stokes Kia, Isuzu, Subaru, Inc., in a claim for breach of contract, conversion, and violation of certain consumer protection laws brought by a purchaser whose car had been repossessed in what was alleged to have been a yo-yo sale.Â  We affirm.
FACTS
In January 2000, Rebecca Brewerâ€™s automobile quit running, and she began shopping for another car.Â  Brewer visited two car dealerships before visiting Stokes Kia.Â  At both of the prior dealerships, Brewer was unable to purchase a car because of her poor credit rating.Â  When Brewer arrived at Stokes Kia and explained her price range, she was shown a 1996 Ford Aspire, which she agreed to purchase.Â  The salesman completed a handwritten buyerâ€™s order, which was signed by Brewer and initialed by the Stokes Kia sales manager.Â  This buyerâ€™s order specified the car to be purchased, the price, and memorialized the acceptance of a one thousand dollar down payment from Brewer for the car.Â  
Next, Brewer met with the Stokes Kia finance manager.Â  The finance manager had her sign a new buyerâ€™s order that had been computer-generated and was stamped â€œVEHICLE DELIVERED SUBJECT TO CREDIT APPROVAL.â€Â  Brewer initialed beside the stamped language.Â  Brewer also signed a retail installment sales contract and security agreement.Â  The retail installment sales contract lists the amount financed for the purchase of the car, $6,609.50; the name of the seller, Stokes Kia-Isuzu Subaru; the annual percentage rate, 21.95%; the number of payments, 36; amount of payments, $252.24; and when the monthly payments begin, February 10, 2000.Â  This form was not signed by a representative of Stokes Kia.Â  Additionally, Brewer signed a bailment agreement.Â  The bailment agreement states: â€œIf dealer is able to provide the Buyer(s) with financing according to the terms set forth in the Sales Agreement, the said Sales Agreement shall be binding upon Buyer(s) and enforceable by Dealer.Â  In the event dealer is unable to provide financing Buyer(s) shall provide their own financing.â€Â  It also says: Â â€œPending credit approval of the Buyer(s) by the financing institution and completion of the sales transaction, delivery of said vehicle by the Dealer is hereby made to Buyer(s) as a convenience to Buyer(s) . . . .â€Â  Brewer admitted nobody at Stokes Kia told her financing had been approved, but she also testified no one had indicated otherwise.Â Â Â  
Several days later, Stokes Kia was having difficulty obtaining financing for Brewer and called to obtain further information about her employment status.Â  When Brewer called back to resolve the question, she was told the dealer was unable to secure financing for her and, in order to keep the car, she would have to get a co-signor or find her own financing.Â  Brewer contacted her bank, but her request for a loan was denied due to her poor credit rating.Â  On January 19, 2000, Brewer received a call from Stokes Kia asking her to return the car, but she refused.Â  Later that evening, a representative of Stokes Kia repossessed the vehicle.Â  After this claim was initiated and depositions had been taken by Brewer, Stokes Kia returned her deposit with interest. 
Brewer commenced this action against Stokes Kia, alleging causes of action for breach of contract; conversion; violations of the Unfair Trade Practices Act; and violation of the Manufacturers, Distributors, and Dealers Act.Â  Approximately one year later, Stokes Kia moved for summary judgment.Â  Nearly three weeks after the motion, Brewer sought to amend her complaint to add six additional causes of action.Â  In June 2001, Judge Smoak denied the motion for summary judgment and granted the motion to amend the complaint.Â  However, upon reconsideration, Judge Smoak granted summary judgment.Â  A motion for reconsideration was timely filed, but was not heard until six months later.Â  By that time, Judge Smoak had retired and the motion for reconsideration was heard by Judge Rawl.Â  Judge Rawl denied the motion, and this appeal followed.Â Â Â  
STANDARD OF REVIEW
A trial courtâ€™s decision to grant a motion for summary judgment is appropriate when there is no genuine issue of material fact so that the moving party is entitled to judgment as a matter of law. Â Gilbert v. Miller, 356 S.C. 25, 28, 586 S.E.2d 861, 863 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  All ambiguities, conclusions, and inferences arising from the evidence must be construed against the moving party.Â  Id.Â  An appellate court will review summary judgment in a liberal manner so as to construe the record in favor of the nonmoving party and give the nonmoving party the benefit of all favorable inferences that might reasonably be drawn
therefrom.  Jackson v. Doe, 342 S.C. 552, 555, 537 S.E.2d 567, 568 (Ct. App. 2000).Â  Additionally, our court is cognizant that summary judgment is a drastic remedy, which must be cautiously invoked so that no person will be improperly deprived of a trial on disputed factual issues.Â  Id.  
LAW/ANALYSIS
Brewer argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because:Â  (1) issues of fact exist as to the existence of a contract; (2) she was not in default and therefore Stokes Kia did not have a right to repossess; and (3) she suffered damages.Â  Brewer further argues that because summary judgment was granted in error, she should have been allowed to amend her complaint to add various other causes of action.
1.     Contract issues 
Brewer argues the trial court erred in granting summary judgment because there were issues of material fact regarding the existence of a contract.Â  To support this argument, she first asserts the contract between Stokes Kia was not conditioned on her credit being approved.Â  We disagree.
A condition precedent to a contract is â€œany fact other than the lapse of time, which, unless excused, must exist or occur before a duty of immediate performance arises.â€Â  Worley v. Yarborough Ford, Inc., 317 S.C. 206, 210, 452 S.E.2d 622, 624 (Ct. App. 1994).Â  â€œThe question of whether a provision â€˜in a contract constitutes a condition precedent is a question of construction dependent on the intent of the parties to be gathered from the language they employ.â€™â€Â  Id. (citations omitted).Â  
Here, the computer-generated buyerâ€™s order contained a stamped declaration that delivery was subject to credit approval, and Brewer admitted to seeing and initialing this declaration.Â Â  Further, Brewer admitted no one at Stokes Kia told her that her credit had been approved.Â  
In addition to the stamp on the signed, computer-generated buyerâ€™s order, a bailment agreement signed by Brewer states: â€œIn the event dealer is unable to provide financing Buyer(s) shall provide their own financing.â€Â  The computer-generated buyerâ€™s order and the bailment agreement make it clear that the sale was not final until financing was arranged.Â  The contract provided that Stokes Kia would attempt to obtain financing for Brewer, but if it could not, the responsibility would become Brewerâ€™s.Â Â  If neither Stokes Kia nor Brewer were able to obtain financing, ownership of the vehicle would remain with Stokes Kia.
In the event we find a condition precedent existed, Brewer further argues there was nothing to indicate the condition was not met, nor was there anything specifying who had to approve her request for credit.Â  However, the bailment agreement explained the deal would be completed â€œ[i]f dealer is able to provide Buyer(s) with financing according to the terms set forth in the Sales Agreement . . . .â€Â  This language vests discretion concerning financing with the dealership.Â  Stokes Kia, like the two dealerships Brewer had previously visited, was unable to find a company to finance Brewerâ€™s purchase.Â  Thus, it became Brewerâ€™s responsibility to find financing on her own.Â  She, too, was unable to find financing.
Brewer also argues the computer-generated buyerâ€™s order was preceded by a handwritten buyerâ€™s order which did not have a condition precedent and that the handwritten order itself constituted a contract.Â  However, the actions of the parties and Brewerâ€™s ultimate signature on the computer-generated buyerâ€™s order demonstrate this handwritten buyerâ€™s order was simply a preliminary negotiation to the final agreement.Â  This is underscored by the fact that no terms besides price were discussed in the handwritten buyerâ€™s order.Â  In fact, it says that the â€œUNPAID BALANCE IS DUE ON DELIVERYâ€ and lists the balance as $5,397.50.Â  If this were the only enforceable contract between the parties, Brewer would be obligated to pay $5,397.50 to own the car.Â  It is undisputed that Brewer was not able to meet that obligation.
Brewer also argues the retail installment contract and security agreement constitute Stokes Kiaâ€™s offer to finance the transaction.Â  It appears from deposition testimony the retail installment contract was signed by Brewer when she met with the finance manager.Â  It was at this time that she also signed the computer-generated buyerâ€™s order.Â  Although Brewer signed the installment contract, it was never signed by Stokes Kia.Â  In fact, Stokes Kia generally does not sign this document until the credit has been approved.Â  Because the document was not signed by Stokes Kia, it is not enforceable against it.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 36-2-201 (2004). 
Additionally, Brewer argues physical delivery of the car by Stokes Kia is either evidence the contract was complete or an indication that legal ownership of the car had transferred.Â  She refers to section 36-2-401 of the South Carolina Code (2004) to support the latter proposition.Â  Section 36-2-401 provides: 

Unless otherwise explicitly agreed title passes to the buyer at the time and place at which the seller completes his performance with reference to the physical delivery of the goods, despite any reservation of a security interest and even though a document of title is to be delivered at a different time or place . . . .Â  

The key phrase from section 36-2-401 is â€œunless otherwise explicitly agreed.â€Â  The agreement between Brewer and Stokes Kia did explicitly state physical delivery of the car was only a convenience provided to the buyer and the sale was pending credit approval.Â  Therefore, pursuant to the agreement, title did not pass at the time of physical delivery.Â  This contract language also prevents introduction of this conduct as evidence the contract was complete.
Finally, in her reply brief, Brewer attempts to argue this case is controlled by Singleton v. Stokes Motors, Inc., 358 S.C. 369, 595 S.E.2d 461 (2004).Â  Singleton involved a yo-yo sale, defined as occurring when: 

The consumer believes a vehicleâ€™s installment or sale is final and the dealer gives the consumer possession of the car â€˜on the spot.â€™Â  The dealer later tells the consumer to return the car because the financing has fallen through.Â  If the consumer does not return the vehicle or agree to rewrite the transaction on less favorable terms, the dealer repossesses the vehicle.Â  

Id. at 380, 595 S.E.2d at 467 (quoting National Consumer Law Center, Unfair and Deceptive Acts and Practices 316 (5th ed. 2001)).Â  The transaction in Singleton involved an unconditional sales contract and conditional bailment agreement, which our supreme court called â€œpatently unfair and deceptive acts.â€Â  Id. at 381, 595 S.E.2d at 468.Â  However, the court determined the dealerships could easily cure the unfairness by explaining in the sales agreement that the sale is conditioned upon the buyer obtaining financing and telling the customers the truth about their credit.Â  Id.Â  at 381-82, 595 S.E.2d at 468.Â  Singleton does not apply to Brewerâ€™s transaction because the buyerâ€™s order did contain a stamp making delivery of the car conditional upon Brewer obtaining financing and because Stokes Kia never told Brewer she had been financed.
Thus, we agree the trial court did not err in granting summary judgment on the basis of the lack of an enforceable contract.
2.     Right to repossess, damages, and amendment of the complaint 
Brewer argues the trial court was also in error when it found Stokes Kia had a right to repossess, when it found there were no damages, and when it denied her motion to amend the complaint.Â  We disagree.
Brewer argues there was no right to repossession because she had not defaulted on the contract.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-5-110 (2002).Â  However, as discussed above, the car was delivered to Brewer subject to credit approval as a convenience extended to her by Stokes Kia.Â  When Brewer was not financed and she was not able to obtain financing on her own, she was unable to complete the transaction.Â  By failing to pay for the car, she defaulted on the contract.Â  When default occurred, Stokes Kia had the right to repossess the car.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 37-5-112 (2002).[1]  
The trial court also supported its grant of summary judgment on the basis that Brewer could not demonstrate any damages.Â  The trial court explained Brewerâ€™s down payment had been returned with interest and though Brewer alleged she could have had a free rental car for four additional days from the time of the sale, she actually used the car from Stokes Kia for eight days.Â  Because we found the trial court was correct in granting summary judgment to Stokes Kia on the basis of the contract issues, it is not necessary that we rule on this issue.Â  See Rule 220(c), SCACR; Futch v. McAllister Towing of Georgetown, Inc., 335 S.C. 598, 613, 518 S.E.2d 591, 598 (1999) (explaining the appellate court need not address remaining issues when disposition of prior issue is
dispositive).

 Finally, Brewerâ€™s argument regarding amendment of her complaint is contingent on our finding the grant of summary judgment was in error.Â  Because we have affirmed the grant of summary judgment this issue must also fail.
CONCLUSION
For the reasons discussed above, the trial courtâ€™s grant of summary judgment is
AFFIRMED.
KITTREDGE and WILLIAMS, JJ., concur.

[1] Providing: â€œUpon default by a consumer with respect to a consumer credit transaction, unless the consumer voluntarily surrenders possession of the collateral or rented property to the creditor, the creditor may take possession of the collateral or rented property without judicial process only if possession can be taken without entry into a dwelling used as a current residence and without the use of force or other breach of the peace.â€
