title: Howard v. Nasser
description: In this will contest case, Appellants appeal the circuit court's order granting summary judgment in favor of the surviving spouse and finding the will was not the product of undue influence.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Leroy J. Howard and John Nasser, Appellants,
v.
JoAnn Nasser, Joey Nasser, Christina Nasser, Ashley Nasser, Leander Nasser, Mary Kaye Barki and Debbie
Coggins, Defendants, of whom JoAnn Nasser is, Respondent.
      
    
  


Appeal From Greenville County
Â Charles B. Simmons, Jr., Acting Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3986
Heard December 8, 2004 â€“ Filed May 2, 2005

REVERSED AND REMANDED


  
    
      
Ben G. Leaphart, of Greenville, for Appellants.
William Wallace Culp, III, of Greenville, for Respondent.
      
    
  

BEATTY, J.:Â  In this will contest case, Leroy J. Howard and John Nasser (collectively Appellants) appeal the circuit courtâ€™s order granting summary judgment for JoAnn Nasser (Respondent), surviving spouse of the decedent Leroy Nasser (Nasser) and personal representative of his estate.Â  Appellants argue the will was invalid because it was the product of undue influence by Respondent.Â  We reverse and remand. 
FACTS
Leroy Howard and John Nasser, the decedentâ€™s nephews, brought an action to contest an April 10, 2000 will of Nasser.Â  The will was properly executed and was admitted to probate.Â  Nasserâ€™s surviving spouse and second wife, Respondent, was appointed as personal representative of his estate.Â  The will left nothing to either Leroy Howard or John Nasser.Â  Instead, Nasser gave $10,000 to each of his great nieces and the remainder of his estate to Respondent.Â  Additionally, Nasser gave Respondent a power of attorney in October of 1999, specifically revoking a previous power of attorney in favor of Leroy Howard.Â  
Nasser had executed two prior wills.Â  The first will, executed on July 30, 1985, left everything to his first wife and appointed Leroy Howard as his personal representative.Â  After Nasserâ€™s first wife died, he executed another will, dated May 19, 1995, that left $50,000 to John Nasser and the residue to Leroy Howard.Â  Leroy Howard was also appointed personal representative of Nasserâ€™s estate.Â  
In August of 1998, Nasser was injured in a fall while in Roanoke, Virginia.Â  Leroy Howard drove Nasser back to Greenville, where he was admitted to the St. Francis Hospital System and released in September of 1998.Â  While recovering from his fall, Nasser met Respondent, who was employed as a housekeeper at the hospital.Â  Respondent obtained a divorce from her first husband, from whom she had been separated for approximately ten years, in April of 1999.Â  On May 24, 1999, Respondent and Nasser were married.Â  The will giving rise to this litigation was executed on April 10, 2000.Â  Nasser died as a result of pancreatic cancer and cirrhosis on May 19, 2000.Â  
Appellants filed a petition in probate court, alleging causes of action for undue influence, lack of capacity, fraud, and tortious interference with an expectancy to inherit.Â  Respondent moved for summary judgment on all causes of action.[1]Â  At the hearing on the motion, Appellants argued that Respondentâ€™s fiduciary relationship with Nasser, along with other evidence, created a presumption of undue influence.Â  In support of their contention, Appellants offered the following evidence:

(1)            Karen R. Hunter, M.D., testified that she diagnosed Nasser with pancreatic cancer in mid-April, 2000.Â  At that time, he appeared ill and was jaundiced, but he did not appear overly distraught about the diagnosis.Â  
(2)            Leroy Howardâ€™s affidavit stated that during the last year of Nasserâ€™s life, his health had deteriorated, and that he believed that Respondent had poisoned his relationship with Nasser, as communication inexplicably broke down and he was not allowed to visit Nasser alone.Â  Additionally, Nasser allegedly withdrew funds in excess of $200,000 from a joint account held by Leroy Howard and Nasser in April of 2000.Â  
(3)            John Nasserâ€™s affidavit also stated that his communication with Nasser decreased dramatically in late 1999, and that Nasser appeared sickly and confused in April of 2000.Â  
(4)            The affidavit of Nicholas M. Franchina, a realtor and friend of the family, stated that in addition to a â€œdramatic change in [Nasserâ€™s] affect, and personality,â€ he noticed on two occasions that someone was listening in on the telephone, and that Mr. Nasser abruptly cut short the conversation and hung up. 
(5)            A local attorney who had prepared Nasserâ€™s two previous wills felt that Nasser was upset about the April 2000 will, and since the disposition was dramatically different from that of the previous wills, he felt uncomfortable and encouraged the Nassers to seek other counsel.
(6)            The durable power of attorney Nasser executed in October of 1999 specifically revoked the previous power of attorney in favor of Leroy Howard.Â  However, the paragraph containing the revocation was in a different font from the rest of the document.Â  

In contrast, the attorney who drafted the April 2000 will testified that Nasser appeared to be of sound mind, and that he freely and voluntarily indicated that he wanted the majority of his estate to go to his wife.Â  Additionally, there was testimony that Leroy Howardâ€™s relationship with Nasser had become strained.Â  Nasser allegedly told the witness that he â€œwould rather throw that money in the garbage can or throw it away than for him to have one cent of my money.â€Â  Moreover, the same witness testified that Leroy Howard called immediately after learning of Nasserâ€™s death to inquire about Nasserâ€™s estate, whereas Respondent seemed much more concerned about Nasserâ€™s death. 
After hearing arguments, the circuit court granted Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment. [2]Â  Specifically, the court ruled that Appellantsâ€™ burden of proving undue influence could not be shifted to Respondent.Â  The court reasoned that Appellants continued to bear the burden of proof even if a confidential/fiduciary relationship existed between Respondent and Nasser.Â  As to the merits of the cause of action for undue influence, the court found there was no evidence to support Appellantsâ€™ claim.Â  This appeal followed. 
STANDARD OF REVIEW
â€œSummary judgment is appropriate when it is clear there is no genuine issue of material fact and the conclusions and inferences to be drawn from the facts are undisputed.â€ McClanahan v. Richland County Council, 350 S.C. 433, 437, 567 S.E.2d 240, 242 (2002).Â  In ruling on a motion for summary judgment, a reviewing court must view the evidence in the light most favorable to the non-moving party.Â  Id. at 438, 567 S.E.2d at 242.Â  Summary judgment is a drastic remedy.Â  Thus, it â€œshould be cautiously invoked so that a litigant will not be improperly deprived of trial on disputed factual issues.â€Â  Cunningham ex rel. Grice v. Helping Hands, Inc., 352 S.C. 485, 491, 575 S.E.2d 549, 552 (2003).
 
DISCUSSION
I. 
Appellants argue the circuit court erred in finding the existence of a confidential/fiduciary relationship between Nasser and Respondent did not shift the burden to Respondent to show the absence of undue influence.Â  Appellants claim Respondentâ€™s status as spouse of the decedent and holder of a power of attorney created a fiduciary relationship that gave rise to the presumption of undue influence.
The procedure outlining the burden of proof in contested will cases is governed by section 62-3-407 of the South Carolina Code of Laws.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-407 (Supp. 2004).Â  This section provides in pertinent part:

In contested cases, petitioners who seek to establish intestacy have the burden of establishing prima facie proof of death, venue, and heirship.Â  Proponents of a will have the burden of establishing prima facie proof of due execution in all cases and, if they are also petitioners, prima facie proof of death and venue. Contestants of a will have the burden of establishing undue influence, fraud, duress, mistake, revocation, or lack of testamentary intent or capacity.Â  Parties have the ultimate burden of persuasion as to matters with respect to which they have the initial burden of proof. 

S.C. Code Ann. 62-3-407 (Supp. 2004); see In re Estate of Cumbee, 333 S.C. 664, 671, 511 S.E.2d 390, 393 (Ct. App. 1999) (â€œProponents of a will have the burden of establishing prima facie proof of due execution in all cases . . . Contestants of a will have the burden of establishing undue influence, fraud, duress, mistake, revocation, or lack of testamentary intent or capacity.â€).Â  In analyzing this code section, our supreme court has explained:

When the formal execution of a will is admitted or proved, a prima facie case in favor of the will is made out, and the burden is then on the contestants to prove undue influence, incapacity or other basis of invalidation.Â  The contestants continue to bear the burden of proof throughout the will contest.Â  In determining whether the contestants sustained such burden, the evidence has to be viewed in the light most favorable to the contestants.

Calhoun v. Calhoun, 277 S.C. 527, 530, 290 S.E.2d 415, 417 (1982).Â  
â€œUndue influence may be proved by circumstantial evidence, but the circumstances relied on to show it must be such as taken together point unmistakenly and convincingly to the fact that the mind of the testator was subjected to that of some other person, so that the will is that of the latter and not of the former.â€Â  Havird v. Schissell, 252 S.C. 404, 410-11, 166 S.E.2d 801, 804 (1969) (citations omitted); In re Last Will and Testament of Smoak, 286 S.C. 419, 424, 334 S.E.2d 806, 809 (1985) (â€œA will contest based on alleged undue influence is most often adjudicated on the basis of circumstantial evidence.â€). 
â€œGenerally, in cases where a will has been set aside for undue influence, there has been evidence either of threats, force, and/or restricted visitation, or of an existing fiduciary relationship.â€Â  Russell v. Wachovia Bank, N.A., 353 S.C. 208, 217, 578 S.E.2d 329, 333 (2003).Â  â€œâ€˜A confidential or fiduciary relationship exists when one imposes a special confidence in another, so that the latter, in equity and good conscience, is bound to act in good faith and with due regard to the interest of the one imposing the confidence.â€™â€Â  In re Estate of Cumbee, 333 S.C. at 672, 511 S.E.2d at 394 (quoting Brown v. Pearson, 326 S.C. 409, 422, 483 S.E.2d 477, 484 (Ct. App. 1997)).
Both parties acknowledge that in contested deed cases a presumption of invalidity arises if the contestants of the deed present evidence that a confidential or fiduciary relationship existed between the grantor and the grantee.Â  See Middleton v. Suber, 300 S.C. 402, 405, 388 S.E.2d 639, 641 (1990) (recognizing that where a â€œconfidential relationshipâ€ exists between a grantor and a grantee, the deed is presumed invalid and the burden is upon the grantee to establish the absence of undue influence); Bullard v. Crawley, 294 S.C. 276, 280-81, 363 S.E.2d 897, 900 (1987) (â€œUndue influence in the procurement of a deed may be shown in two ways.Â  The party challenging the deed may show the existence of a confidential relationship between the grantor and the grantee.Â  Once a confidential relationship is shown, the deed is presumed invalid.Â  The burden then shifts to the grantee to affirmatively show the absence of undue influence.â€); Hudson v. Leopold, 288 S.C. 194, 196, 341 S.E.2d 137, 138 (1986)(â€œA fiduciary relationship between the grantor and grantee may give rise to a presumption of undue influence, thus shifting the burden of proof to the grantee to rebut the presumption.â€). 
However, because the instant case involves a will, the central question in this appeal is whether this presumption, which affects the burden of proof, is applicable in the context of a contested will.Â  The parties have not presented nor has our research revealed any case law providing definitive guidance on this issue.Â  However, a recent case of our supreme court appears to implicitly recognize that the presumption of invalidity in deed cases applies to will cases.Â  Dixon v. Dixon, 362 S.C. 388, 608 S.E.2d 849 (2005).
In Dixon, Mother, who was elderly, conveyed her property to Son.Â  At the same time the deed was executed, Mother signed an agreement prepared by Son whereby he agreed to care for Mother and maintain her residence.Â Â  Following a confrontation approximately three years later, Mother asked Son to leave her home, changed the locks on the home, and requested that Son re-convey the title to the property to her.Â  When Son refused, Mother filed an action to set aside the deed.Â  Mother claimed undue influence as one of her grounds challenging the deed.Â  Specifically, she asserted that because she and Son were in a confidential relationship, Son had the burden of proving that he did not unduly influence her and he failed to meet that burden.Â  As a threshold matter, our supreme court found a confidential relationship existed between the parties.Â  The court ultimately concluded that Son proved that he did not unduly influence Mother.Â  In reaching this decision, the court utilized the principles of undue influence applicable in contested will cases.Â  The court relied on precedent from other jurisdictions which has found that â€œthe analysis is the same regardless of whether the underlying document sought to be set aside on the grounds that the plaintiff was unduly influenced is a will or a deed.â€Â  Dixon, 362 S.C. at 398 n.7, 608 S.E.2d at 854 n.7.Â  Based on these cases, the court recognized â€œ[m]ost of our jurisprudence on the issue of undue influence involves a contestant seeking to set aside a will, rather than a deed . . ., nonetheless, we find no reason why this discrepancy should change our analysis.â€ Id.
In addition to Dixon, we find secondary authority supports the application of the presumption to contested will cases.Â  Concerning this issue, the Restatement of Property provides in relevant part:

A presumption of undue influence arises if the alleged wrongdoer was in a confidential relationship with the donor and there were suspicious circumstances surrounding the preparation, formulation, or execution of the donative transfer, whether the transfer was by gift, trust, will, will substitute, or a donative transfer of any other type.Â  The effect of the presumption is to shift to the proponent the burden of going forward with the evidence, not the burden of persuasion.Â  The presumption justifies a judgment for the contestant as a matter of law only if the proponent does not come forward with evidence to rebut the presumption.Â  

Restatement (Third) of Property:Â  Wills and Other Donative Transfers Â§ 8.3 cmt. f (2003) (emphasis added).Â  
We interpret the foregoing to mean that if the contestants of a duly executed will provide evidence that a confidential/fiduciary relationship existed sufficient to raise the presumption, the proponents of the will must offer evidence in rebuttal.Â  We emphasize that although the proponents of the will must present evidence in rebuttal, they do not have to affirmatively disprove the existence of undue influence.Â  Instead, the contestants of the will still retain the ultimate burden of proof to invalidate the will.Â  See S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-3-407 (Supp. 2004) (â€œParties have the ultimate burden of persuasion as to matters with respect to which they have the initial burden of proof.â€); Calhoun, 277 S.C. at 530, 290 S.E.2d at 417 (â€œThe contestants continue to bear the burden of proof throughout the will contest.â€); Smith v. Whetstone, 209 S.C. 78, 84, 39 S.E.2d 127, 129 (1946) (stating in case where will is formally executed the burden of proof is on the contestant to prove undue influence â€œand this burden remains on him to the endâ€). 
To summarize, â€œ[w]here the contestants introduce testimony raising a presumption of undue influence by a beneficiary sustaining a confidential or fiduciary relation toward the testator, the issue should be submitted to the jury, as where, in addition to the factor of confidential relations, there also appear the further facts of an unnatural disposition making the person charged with the undue influence chief beneficiary, and that such person generally dominated the testatrix.â€Â  Moorer v. Bull, 212 S.C. 146, 149, 46 S.E.2d 681, 682 (1948) (citations omitted).Â  However, â€œ[a] mere showing of opportunity and even of a motive to exercise undue influence does not justify a submission of that issue to a jury, unless there is additional evidence that such influence was actually utilized.Â  General influence is not enough.Â  A contestant must show that the influence was brought directly to bear upon the testamentary act.â€Â  Mock v. Dowling, 266 S.C. 274, 277, 222 S.E.2d 773, 774 (1976).Â  â€œThe influence must be of such a degree that it dominated the testatorâ€™s will, took away his free agency, and prevented the exercise of judgment and choice by him.Â  If the testator had the testamentary capacity to dispose of his property and was free and unrestrained in his volition at the time of making the will, the influence that may have inspired it or some provision of it will not be â€˜undue influence.â€™â€Â  In re Last Will and Testament of Smoak, 286 S.C. at 424, 334 S.E.2d at 809.
II. 
Appellants contend the circuit court erred in finding that they had not proved that undue influence was exerted upon Nasser.
Viewing the facts in the light most favorable to Appellants and in the context of the above-outlined principles, we hold a genuine issue of material fact was created regarding Appellantsâ€™ claim of undue influence.Â  Initially, we note the formal execution of the will is undisputed, and thus, is presumed valid.Â  Furthermore, we find, and the parties appear to agree, that a confidential/fiduciary relationship existed between Nasser and Respondent.Â  In addition to the confidential relationship by way of marriage, Respondent admitted at oral argument that the power of attorney that Nasser gave to Respondent created a fiduciary relationship.Â  See In re Estate of Cumbee, 333 S.C. at 672-73, 511 S.E.2d at 394 (finding in will contest that fiduciary relationship, which created the presumption of undue influence, existed between son and mother where son had motherâ€™s power of attorney and managed her finances); see also Chapman v. Citizens & S. Natâ€™l Bank of South Carolina, 302 S.C. 469, 477, 395 S.E.2d 446, 451 (Ct. App. 1990) (â€œ[W]e hold that when a husband or wife reposes in the other a trust to do or not do an act relating to the corpus of his estate after his or her death a confidential relationship shall be deemed to have existed if the one in whom the confidence is reposed has the power to abuse the confidence to his or her advantage.â€).
Appellants did not rely solely on the existence of a confidential/fiduciary relationship, but additionally offered the following evidence in support of their claim of undue influence:Â  (1) Nasser was physically infirm as a result of a terminal illness prior to the execution of the will; (2) the disposition of Nasserâ€™s estate was significantly different from his two prior wills; (3) Respondent was present at the meetings with the attorneys to discuss the contents of the new will; (4) Nasserâ€™s relationship with his nephews became strained and the frequency of family visits was limited after Nasserâ€™s remarriage; (5) Nicholas Franchina, a member of the extended family, noticed a change in Nasserâ€™s disposition and believed someone was monitoring Nasserâ€™s telephone conversations; and (6) Joseph Francis, Jr., an attorney who discussed estate planning with Nasser and Respondent, refused to draft Nasserâ€™s will because he believed Nasser was troubled by the changes.Â  We believe this evidence was sufficient to require Respondent to present evidence rebutting the presumption of invalidity.Â  
In contrast to Appellantsâ€™ evidence, Respondent offered the following evidence: (1) Nasser traveled to Pennsylvania shortly before his death to attend a family event; (2) treating physicians did not discern any mental infirmity; (3) the attorney who prepared the final will believed Nasser had the requisite mental and physical capacity to dispose of his estate and that Nasser and his nephew had a â€œfalling outâ€; (4) a stockbroker, who handled Nasserâ€™s investments in April 2000, testified that Nasser did not want his nephew to have any of his money; and (5) Respondent denied she used Nasserâ€™s power of attorney, restricted his family visits, or monitored his telephone conversations. 
Because there exists a conflict in the evidence, thus creating a genuine issue of material fact, we find the circuit court improperly granted summary judgment in favor of Respondent.Â  See Byrd v. Byrd, 279 S.C. 425, 431, 308 S.E.2d 788, 791-92 (1983) (finding in will contest case that issue of undue influence was properly submitted to the jury where: testator was physically and mentally infirm prior to and contemporaneous with the execution of the will; son, who was the principal beneficiary of the will and in a confidential/fiduciary relationship with testator, threatened to place testator in a nursing home and attempted to restrict visits between testator and his other children; and the will was executed less than six months prior to testatorâ€™s death); Moorer, 212 S.C. at 149, 46 S.E.2d at 681-82 (holding issue of undue influence in contested will case was properly submitted to the jury where there was evidence that testatorâ€™s son was in a confidential/fiduciary relationship with his mother, mother was in fear of him, and he indicated an intention to procure for himself her estate).
Again, we emphasize that the burden of proof as to undue influence remains on Appellants throughout the will contest.Â  In reversing the circuit court, we offer no opinion regarding Appellantsâ€™ success on the merits.Â  We merely find that Appellants offered sufficient evidence to survive summary judgment.Â  
Accordingly, the decision of the circuit court is
REVERSED AND REMANDED.
HUFF, J. and CURETON,
A.J.

[1]Â  Pursuant to section 62-1-302 of the South Carolina Code of Laws, the parties consented to remove the action from probate court to circuit court.Â  S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 62-1-302(c) (Supp. 2004) (â€œNotwithstanding the exclusive jurisdiction of the probate court . . . any action or proceeding filed in the probate court and relating to the following subject matters, on motion of a party . . . must be removed to the circuit court and in these cases the circuit court shall proceed upon the matter de novo. . . .â€).
[2]Â  Although the circuit court judge granted Respondentâ€™s motion for summary judgment on all causes of actions, Appellants only appeal the grant of summary judgment as to undue influence.Â  Accordingly, we have limited our analysis solely to the cause of action involving undue influence.

title: State v. Preslar
description: In this criminal case, appellant was convicted of two counts of intimidation of a witness.  The charges of intimidation of a witness stemmed from Appellantâ€™s writing letters from jail asking his daughter not to proceed with twelve counts of criminal sexual conduct charges.  At trial, the Circuit Judge allowed only one of the criminal sexual conduct charges to be submitted to the jury. Appellant alleges error because this evidence placed his character in issue.  The State avers that the underlying criminal sexual conduct charge was a part of the res gestae.
text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals


  
    
      
The State, Respondent,
v.
Phillip W. Preslar, Appellant.
      
    
  


Appeal From York County
John C. Hayes, III, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3987
Heard April 4, 2005 â€“ Filed May 2, 2005 

AFFIRMED


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defender Robert M. Pachak, of Columbia, for Appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, Assistant Deputy Attorney General Salley W. Elliott, and Assistant Attorney General David Spencer, all of Columbia; and Solicitor Thomas E. Pope, of York, for Respondent.
      
    
  


ANDERSON, J.: Â Phillip Wayne Preslar appeals from his convictions and sentences for two counts of intimidation of a witness.Â  He contends the trial court erred in allowing reference to the prior charges of criminal sexual conduct, the pending charge to which the victim of the intimidation was the victim and chief witness.Â  We affirm.
FACTUAL/PROCEDURAL BACKGROUND
Preslar was charged with twelve counts of criminal sexual conduct (CSC) against his daughter, Melissa.Â  While awaiting trial on the CSC charges, Preslar mailed two handwritten letters seeking to convince Melissa to drop the charges.Â  The first letter was sent to â€œMelissa, Chris & new baby girl.â€Â  The letter stated:

[H]owâ€™s your daughter? or my granddaughter if I may ask?Â  I donâ€™t know her name or how much she weighed when born.Â  Could you write me and let me know? [M]aybe send some pictures of you all!!Â  I would be very greatful [sic]. . . . I know that youâ€™ll take really good care of her.Â  Please do your best, and let her know that I love her, please do this for me Melissa. . . . .
. . . I just talked with my lawyer and did not get very good news from him. Â Seems they want me to plead guilty to Criminal Sexual Conduct 2nd degree.Â  It carries 15 years.Â  Missy, thatâ€™s a long time, and I probably wonâ€™t make it out alive.Â  Even if I do, I wonâ€™t be able to survive, because I wonâ€™t be able to work with a criminal record like the one Iâ€™ll have.Â  Maybe I should just ask for the Death Penalty because itâ€™s more or less what it will be. God, I donâ€™t know what to do now.Â  What should I do now? 
I have to ask you this because you are the only one who can be happy with the results and outcome of this whole situation.Â  I guess it comes down to what you want the Justice System to do to me, for you.Â  I really want you to know that my life is in your hands at this time, and only you can do whatâ€™s necessary to change what happens to me. I keep hearing that you are going to drop the charges, but I just donâ€™t know.Â  Melissa, if you have any part of my heart, please think about dropping the charges.Â  I am not begging you to, just asking please.Â  I just donâ€™t think I can make it in Prison again, especially 15 years.Â  Missy, my lawyer says that I can take this to Trial, but I donâ€™t want to drag out all the shit that they will put any of us thru, if you know what I mean.Â  They will drag out everyoneâ€™s past by doing a trial and more indictments or warrants could and will come up on others involved.
I will try to keep from going to trial because I donâ€™t want them to antagonize you any more than they already have.Â  Melissa, it is very important that you do whatever you do at your own free will, and I want you to know that in no way am I threatening you or anyone else. I just hope and pray that this time youâ€™ll save my life from this crooked Justice System. . . . Once again Melissa, [p]lease do what you can to drop these charges so we donâ€™t have to suffer any more heartache that the past is going to bring up. . . . I pray that you will help me Missy.Â  (Emphasis in original).

Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  In a second letter, addressed to Melissaâ€™s sister, Preslar wrote:

Mandy, tell your sister Missy, not to take this as a threat, or personal, or as an effort to get her to drop these charges, Mandy, by no means am I a snitch, but I will not stand by and give my life to SCâ€™s prison system for accusations given to NC, almost 7 years ago.Â  Not when God, myself, and other people know about Chris and Missyâ€™s past which they explained to me and my friend just 14 months ago, (68 chev, late 1994?).Â  I donâ€™t by no means want to see Melissa hurt by her past with Chris but God wonâ€™t let me stand by and not bring this in to the open.Â  You know, maybe its Godâ€™s will that put me here to show this anyway since I never done anything about it back then when I should have and they were sleeping together in Indian Land.Â  I am going to hold off talking with any detectives about this until after Jan. 10th, when Court starts back up here.Â  Everything depends on whether this goes to trial or not.Â  I truly believe that God is using me to bring other people out of their misery of their own hidden sins in which only God and themselves know of!! (God works in mysterious ways). Only God & Melissa have the power to change the outcome of this unforeseen travsety [sic] of all our lives.Â  I Hope and Pray that God will touch Missyâ€™s heart just as he has mine.

Preslar was indicted for two counts of intimidation of a witness under section 16-9-340 of the South Carolina Code (2003).Â  Prior to trial, Preslar moved to prohibit the State from presenting any evidence or mentioning the underlying CSC charges.Â  Preslarâ€™s counsel alleged the mention of the CSC charges would be unduly prejudicial and would confuse the jury.Â  The State maintained the underlying charges had to be identified in order to demonstrate why the two letters were so threatening to Melissa.
The court allowed the State to articulate that Preslar was charged with criminal sexual conduct without mentioning the number of charges or that he was currently incarcerated.Â  Portions of the letters were redacted so only those sections specifically alleged to be intimidating were allowed into evidence.
During the trial, it was explained that Preslar was charged with CSC.Â  The State informed the jury that Melissa was the alleged victim in the case and the primary witness if it should proceed to trial.Â  Melissa professed that bringing the charges against her father scared her, â€œbut on the other handÂ  [made her] happyâ€ because â€œhe couldnâ€™t mess with [her] no more.â€
Melissa described in detail why the first letter was intimidating to her.Â  As the alleged victim of Preslarâ€™s CSC charges, the references to her daughter made her very uneasy.Â  Melissa stated she â€œdidnâ€™t want him to know her or her to know him.â€Â  She later addressed the threat: â€œJust my daughter period, donâ€™t want him to know her or have anything to do with her or see her or touch her or anything.â€
The references to â€œmore indictments or warrantsâ€ made Melissa afraid for her husband.Â  She announced to the jury that she and her husband had sexual relations when she was still a minor, at sixteen.Â  Melissa testified she was â€œscaredâ€ Preslar would seek charges against her husband, Chris, even though the two married in 1997.
As to the second letter, Melissaâ€™s main concern was for her husband.Â  The threats that Preslar would expose their relationship when she was only sixteen made her afraid her husband could go to jail.Â  She articulated the claims by Preslar made her â€œ[h]esitant on going forth.â€Â  The jury found Preslar guilty on both counts of intimidating a witness.
STANDARD OF REVIEW
In criminal cases, the appellate court sits to review errors of law only. State v. Wilson, 345 S.C. 1, 545 S.E.2d 827 (2001); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This court is bound by the trial courtâ€™s factual findings unless they are clearly erroneous.Â  State v. Quattlebaum, 338 S.C. 441, 527 S.E.2d 105 (2000); State v. Landis, 362 S.C. 97, 606 S.E.2d 503 (Ct. App. 2004); see also State v. Abdullah, 357 S.C. 344, 349, 592 S.E.2d 344, 347 (Ct. App. 2004)(â€œOn appeal from a suppression hearing, this court is bound by the circuit courtâ€™s factual findings if any evidence supports the findings.â€).Â  This same standard of review applies to preliminary factual findings in determining the admissibility of certain evidence in criminal cases.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Davis, Op. No. 3970 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 28, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 16 at 55).
On review, we are limited to determining whether the trial judge abused his discretion.Â  State v. Reed, 332 S.C. 35, 503 S.E.2d 747 (1998); State v. Bowie, 360 S.C. 210, 600 S.E.2d 112 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  This Court does not re-evaluate the facts based on its own view of the preponderance of the evidence but simply determines whether the trial judgeâ€™s ruling is supported by any evidence.Â  Wilson, 345 S.C. at 6, 545 S.E.2d at 829; State v. Mattison, 352 S.C. 577, 575 S.E.2d 852 (Ct. App. 2003).
The admission or exclusion of evidence is left to the sound discretion of the trial judge.Â  State v. Gaster, 349 S.C. 545, 564 S.E.2d 87 (2002); State v. Staten, Op. No. 3955 (S.C. Ct. App. filed March 7, 2005) (Shearouse Adv. Sh. No. 12 at 22).Â  A courtâ€™s ruling on the admissibility of evidence will not be reversed on appeal absent an abuse of discretion or the commission of legal error, which results in prejudice to the defendant.Â  State v. McLeod, 362 S.C. 73, 606 S.E.2d 215 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  An abuse of discretion occurs when the trial courtâ€™s ruling is based on an error of law.Â  State v. McDonald, 343 S.C. 319, 540 S.E.2d 464 (2000); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  In order for an error to warrant reversal, the error must result in prejudice to the appellant.Â  See State v. Beck, 342 S.C. 129, 536 S.E.2d 679 (2000); see also State v. Wyatt, 317 S.C. 370, 453 S.E.2d 890 (1995) (error without prejudice does not warrant reversal).
LAW/ANALYSIS
Preslar contends the trial court erred in allowing testimony regarding the nature of his charges.Â  He maintains it was unduly prejudicial for the jury to be told the underlying charges were for CSC, and the testimony should have been excluded as improper character evidence or as a reference to a prior bad act.Â  We disagree.
I.Â  INTIMIDATION OF A WITNESS
In South Carolina, intimidation of a witness is a statutory offense consisting of the following elements:

(1)Â Â Â Â  an unlawful threat or force;
(2)Â Â Â Â  to intimidate or impede a witness in the discharge of his duty;

OR

to destroy, impede, or attempt to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any court.

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-340(A) (2003).
II.Â  RES GESTAE
The res gestae theory recognizes that evidence of other bad acts may be an integral part of the crime with which the defendant is charged or may be needed to aid the fact finder in understanding the context in which the crime occurred.Â  State v. Fletcher, __S.C.__, 609 S.E.2d 572 (Ct. App. 2005); State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Our supreme court discussed the res gestae theory in State v. Adams, 322 S.C. 114, 470 S.E.2d 366 (1996):

One of the accepted bases for the admissibility of evidence of other crimes arises when such evidence â€œfurnishes part of the context of the crimeâ€ or is necessary to a â€œfull presentationâ€ of the case, or is so intimately connected with and explanatory of the crime charged against the defendant and is so much a part of the setting of the case and its â€œenvironmentâ€ that its proof is appropriate in order â€œto complete the story of the crime on trial by proving its immediate context or the â€˜res gestaeâ€™â€ or the â€œuncharged offense is â€˜so linked together in point of time and circumstances with the crime charged that one cannot be fully shown without proving the other . . .â€™ [and is thus] part of the res gestae of the crime charged.â€

Id. at 122, 470 S.E.2d at 370-71 (quoting United States v. Masters, 622 F.2d 83, 86 (4th Cir. 1980)).Â  When evidence is admissible to provide this â€œfull presentationâ€ of the offense, there is â€œno reason to fragmentize the event under inquiry by suppressing parts of the res gestae.â€Â  State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 133, 606 S.E.2d 508, 517 (Ct. App. 2004) (internal quotations omitted).Â  Under the res gestae principle, it is important that the temporal proximity of the prior bad act be closely related to the charged crime.Â  Fletcher, __S.C. at __, 609 S.E.2d at 585.Â  Even if the evidence is relevant under this theory, prior to admission the trial judge should determine whether its probative value clearly outweighs any unfair prejudice.Â  Rule 403, SCRE; Fletcher, __S.C. at __, 609 S.E.2d at 585.
Section 16-9-340 of the South Carolina Code provides: 

(A) It is unlawful for a person by threat or force to:
  
(1) intimidate or impede a judge, magistrate, juror, witness, or potential juror or witness, arbiter, commissioner, or member of any commission of this State or any other official of any court, in the discharge of his duty as such;Â  or
(2) destroy, impede, or attempt to obstruct or impede the administration of justice in any court.
  

S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-9-340 (2003).
In the case sub judice, the evidence was properly admitted under the res gestae theory.Â  The underlying CSC charges were a necessary and integral part of the crime for which Preslar was charged.Â  The nature of those crimesâ€”the explanation that Preslar allegedly victimized his daughter Melissaâ€”was inextricably interwoven in the fabric of the charge of intimidation of Melissa as the victim and primary witness in the case against
Preslar.
In order for the jury to fully understand why Melissa would be threatened by Preslarâ€™s references to her baby girl, the jury had to understand what Melissa accused Preslar of doing to her.Â  Without reference to the underlying CSC charges, the jury would not be able to discern the context in which the questions became threats.Â  The reference to the CSC charges was necessary for a full presentation of the evidence to the jury.Â  The explanation that Preslar was charged with CSC and Melissa was his victim is archetypical res gestae evidence.Â  Moreover, the probative value of the evidence outweighed its prejudicial effect.Â  See State v. Wood, 362 S.C. 520, 608 S.E.2d 435 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Concomitantly, the trial court did not abuse its discretion in admitting the evidence that Preslar was charged with CSC and Melissa was the victim and primary witness in the case.
III.Â  RELEVANCE
For evidence to be admissible, it must be relevant.Â  Rules 401 & 402, SCRE; State v. Sweat, 362 S.C. 117, 606 S.E.2d 508 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œAll relevant evidence is admissible, except as otherwise provided by the Constitution of the United States, the Constitution of the State of South Carolina, statutes, these rules, or by other rules promulgated by the Supreme Court of South Carolina.â€Â  Rule 402, SCRE; State v. Gillian, 360 S.C. 433, 457-58, 602 S.E.2d 62, 75 (Ct. App. 2004) (internal quotations omitted).Â  
Relevant evidence is defined as â€œevidence having any tendency to make the existence of any fact that is of consequence to the determination of the action more probable or less probable than it would be without the evidence.â€Â  Rule 401, SCRE; State v. Pagan, 357 S.C. 132, 142, 591 S.E.2d 646, 651 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  Under Rule 401, evidence is relevant if it has a direct bearing upon and tends to establish or make more or less probable the matter in controversy.Â  In re Care and Treatment of Corley, 353 S.C. 202, 577 S.E.2d 451 (2003); State v. Adams, 354 S.C. 361, 580 S.E.2d 785 (Ct. App. 2003).Â  â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice.â€Â  Rule 403,
SCRE.
The evidence of Preslarâ€™s charges for CSC was absolutely necessary and relevant for the jury to determine why the letters written to Melissa were threatening and intimidating.Â  While the nature of the charges was prejudicial, as is any evidence against the defendant in a criminal trial, the evidence was essential to proving the elements of the crime for which Preslar is charged.Â  The probative value of the evidence outweighed its prejudicial effect.Â  Apodictically, the trial court properly allowed the testimony regarding Preslarâ€™s charges for CSC.
CONCLUSION
The testimony explaining Preslarâ€™s prior charges for CSC to the jury was necessary to explain the context or the res gestae of the crime of intimidating a witness under section 16-9-340.Â  Additionally, the evidence was not unduly prejudicial so as to outweigh its probative value.Â  The trial court did not abuse its discretion.Â  Accordingly, Preslarâ€™s convictions and sentences are
AFFIRMED.
 BEATTY and SHORT, JJ., concur.

text:
Murphy v. Jefferson Pilot


THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Court of Appeals

  
    
      
Elizabeth Murphy, Appellant,
v.
Jefferson Pilot Communications Company, WCSC, Inc., d/b/a WCSC Channel 5, and Donald M. Feldman, Defendants, of whom Jefferson Pilot Communications Company and
WCSC, Inc., d/b/a WCSC Channel 5 are, Respondents.
_____________________
        Christopher Murphy, Appellant,
      
    
  

v.

  
    
      
Jefferson Pilot Communications Company, WCSC,
Inc., d/b/a WCSC Channel 5, and Donald M. Feldman, Defendants, of whom,
Jefferson Pilot Communications Company and WCSC, Inc., d/b/a WCSC Channel 5 are Respondents.
      
    
  


Appeal From Charleston County
Thomas L. Hughston, Jr., Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 3988
Heard March 10, 2005 â€“ Filed May 2, 2005

AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART,
AND REMANDED 


  
    
      
John E. Parker and Ronnie L. Crosby, both of Hampton, for Appellants. 
John J. Kerr, of Charleston, for Respondents.
      
    
  

STILWELL, J.:Â  Elizabeth Murphy filed an action against Jefferson Pilot Communications Company (Jefferson Pilot), WCSC, Inc. d/b/a WCSC Channel 5 (WCSC), and Donald M. Feldman, alleging, inter alia, defamation and intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  Elizabethâ€™s husband, Christopher Murphy, filed a companion claim alleging loss of consortium.Â  The trial court directed verdicts in favor of WCSC and Jefferson Pilot.Â  The jury returned a verdict against Feldman, awarding the Murphys substantial actual and punitive damages.Â  The Murphys appeal.Â  We affirm in part, reverse in part, and remand. 
FACTS
Donald Feldman served as â€œAssistant VP Newsâ€ for Jefferson Pilot and was the news director of WCSC, a Charleston television station and Jefferson Pilot subsidiary.Â  He reported directly to the general manager of Jefferson Pilot.Â  Feldman met Sandra Senn, a local attorney, and convinced her to become a voluntary panelist on a political talk show broadcast by WCSC entitled â€œCarolina Gang.â€Â  Senn, a former partner in the Stuckey Law Firm, had recently started her own firm.Â  Elizabethâ€™s father, James Stuckey, was the senior partner of the Stuckey Law Firm.Â  Senn and the firm were involved in a dispute regarding business issues relating to Sennâ€™s departure from the firm, and Senn mentioned her frustrations springing from the dispute in casual conversations with Feldman.Â  
On July 23, 1999, Feldman telephoned Senn and said that he had just arrived in Atlanta on a flight from Charleston.Â  Feldman told Senn that Elizabeth was on his flight and, while very intoxicated, made slanderous remarks about Senn and WCSC.Â  
A couple of days later, Feldman electronically mailed Senn stating: 

I have decided to take an ACTIVE roll [sic] in dealing with this woman.Â  I have come up with my own plan to deal with her. . . . After thinking about it, I am determined not to let this woman attempt to destroy your reputation and my plan will scare the crap out of her.Â  It was selfish of me to stay out of it. 

Later the same week, Feldman told Senn he sent a letter (the Letter) to Elizabeth via courier.Â  Feldman provided Senn with a copy of the Letter.Â  The Letter was written on WCSC stationery and stated:Â  

Dear Ms. Stuckey:[1]Â  
After what I felt were disturbing and potentially Liable [sic] Statements aboard Delta Fight 852 from Charleston to Atlanta on July 23, 1999. [sic]Â  There are several issues I am compelled to discuss with you. 
Your unsubstantiated comments against Jefferson-Pilot Communications, WCSC News, Sandy Senn and Me are at the least tasteless and could force our company to take legal action against you and your law firm.Â  
As you so clearly stated, Ms. Senn is a WCSC Air Personality.Â  Therefore, WCSC has a moral as well as a financial interest in protecting her reputation and that of our News Department and itsâ€™ [sic] programs.Â  It is one thing to criticize an air personalities [sic] delivery, but it is quite another to loudly and publicly discuss their bedroom habits and personal disputes between you, your Law Firm, and her.Â  I am also deeply disturbed that you would question my hiring practices and the motives behind them.Â  I have been in Television News Management for thirty years and maintain WCSCâ€™s news as the highest rated and most respected in the market.Â  
As a result, I have instructed a member of our staff to contact Delta Airlines to obtain the passenger manifest and the flight attendant service log for the flight we were on.Â  Atlanta Passenger Service Agent Heath Hamrick will also be contacted.Â  As you recall, he was the individual who repeatedly told you to keep your voice down after our late arrival in Atlanta.Â  
I intent [sic] to use the passenger service manifest to determine which passengers, if any, heard your comments.Â  I will then contact Frank Magid Associates, our research firm, and ask them to interview any Charleston area passengers to see if your statements will affect their perceptions and viewing habits of Channel Five and Carolina Gang.Â  They will also ask if the perceptions of Ms. Senn have changed.Â  
The flight attendant service log will be used to determine how many bottles [sic] alcohol you were served on the flight.Â  
Once I have this information, I intend to turn to our legal department.Â  They will advise me whether to tell Ms. Senn of the incident and whether our company should take legal action against you and your law firm.Â  If you care to discuss this incident further, please contact me at 402-5740.Â  
In the end, this matter could become far more embarrassing for you and your law firm than for Jefferson Pilot Communications, Ms. Senn, or me.Â  
I would hope we can resolve this matter quickly before there is any more damage to the reputations of anyone.Â  
Sincerely, 
Donald M. Feldman
Vice-President/News Director

Subsequently, Feldman told Senn that Elizabeth came to WCSC on two occasions to discuss entering into a civil agreement to refrain from any further defamation of Senn.Â  Senn testified she assisted Feldman in the preparation of the agreement, but never saw a signed copy.Â  At that time, Feldman told Senn that Elizabeth was on the plane with a man who was not her husband. Â On another occasion, Feldman told Senn he had the passenger manifest and the drink log from the flight.Â  
In late September of 1999, Senn gave a copy of the Letter to Dale DuTremble, the attorney representing her in the dispute with the Stuckey Law Firm.Â  Senn told DuTremble she wanted the airplane defamation incident resolved along with her other dispute with the Stuckey Law Firm.Â  DuTremble met with Feldman at WCSC to discuss the Letter.Â  At the meeting, Feldman repeated all the allegations he claimed occurred on the airplane and reiterated that Elizabeth was traveling with a man other than her husband.Â  Feldman told DuTremble he had the passenger manifest and the drink log, but would not reveal them as he was protecting his source at Delta.Â  
DuTremble informed Susan Wall, the attorney representing the Stuckey Law Firm in its dispute with Senn, of Elizabethâ€™s alleged conduct on the airplane.Â  Wall called Elizabeth.Â  Elizabeth denied having any knowledge of the airplane incident and, subsequent to her conversation with Wall, realized she was attending a soccer game and birthday party in Charleston when the airplane incident allegedly occurred.Â  Elizabeth did not see the Letter, supposedly sent to her in July, until November.Â  
Elizabeth showed the Letter to Stuckey, who called Tom Waring, an attorney who represented WCSC.Â  On November 16, Waring talked with Elizabeth and Stuckey and then contacted Rita Oâ€™Neill, WCSCâ€™s general manager.Â  Oâ€™Neill called Feldman to find out what was going on.Â  Feldman told her about the alleged incident on the airplane and stated Elizabeth attacked Senn and the â€œCarolina Gang.â€Â  Feldman also told Oâ€™Neill that the former station manager, Chuck Wing, gave permission to write the letter, and that Wing edited the letter.Â  Feldman indicated that Dan McAlister, general counsel for Jefferson Pilot, probably saw the Letter.Â  
The next day, Waring went to WCSC and met with Feldman and Oâ€™Neill.Â  Feldman produced a copy of the Letter and stated that he had disposed of the passenger manifest and drink log.Â  Feldman told Oâ€™Neill and Waring it was his duty to respond to Elizabeth to protect the station, and he had permission from Wing to write the Letter.Â  
DuTremble testified that beginning in either late 1999 or early 2000, Feldmanâ€™s story began to unravel.Â  All parties finally realized that Elizabeth was not on the flight as Feldman alleged, and obviously Feldman never had the manifest or log as he originally insisted.Â  In November of 2000, Feldman was arrested on embezzlement charges and, at the time of trial, was incarcerated in federal prison.Â  After his arrest, it became clear the entire incident involving Elizabeth never occurred and was entirely fabricated by Feldman.Â  
As a result of Feldmanâ€™s defamatory allegations, Elizabeth sought psychiatric treatment and was diagnosed with a major depressive episode, severe major depression, and severe anxiety.Â  Elizabeth took a medical leave from the practice of law.Â  
In 2001, the Murphys filed suit against Jefferson Pilot, WCSC, and Feldman.Â  The Murphys alleged Feldman made slanderous statements about Elizabeth, which he published in the Letter and to Senn.Â  The Murphys alleged Feldmanâ€™s actions were performed within the scope of his employment with WCSC and as an agent for WCSC and Jefferson Pilot.Â  In addition, they alleged Feldmanâ€™s conduct amounted to intentional infliction of emotional distress.Â  
The action was tried before a jury over an eight-day period.Â  The trial court denied the Murphysâ€™ motions for directed verdicts on liability, and granted the directed verdict motions of WCSC and Jefferson Pilot based on â€œpublic policy.â€Â  The trial court then submitted the case to the jury on only the issue of damages as to Feldman.Â  The jury returned a verdict for Elizabeth of $3,009,268 in actual damages and $3,000,000 in punitive damages.Â  The jury returned a verdict in favor of Christopher Murphy for $3,000,000 in actual damages due to loss of consortium.Â  
The Murphys filed a motion to alter or amend the judgment pursuant to Rule 59(e), SCRCP, and in the alternative a motion for a new trial, arguing the trial court erred in directing verdicts in favor of Jefferson Pilot and WCSC and in denying the Murphysâ€™ motion for directed verdicts.Â  The trial court denied the post-trial motions.Â  The Murphys appeal.Â 
 

  LAW/ANALYSIS

  STANDARD OF REVIEW
  In ruling on a motion for directed verdict the court must view the evidence and all reasonable inferences in the light most favorable to the nonmoving party.Â  Gilliland v. Doe, 357 S.C. 197, 199, 592 S.E.2d 626, 627 (2004).Â  The court must determine the elements of the action alleged and whether any evidence existed on each element.Â  First State
  Sav. & Loan v. Phelps, 299 S.C. 441, 446, 385 S.E.2d 821, 824 (1989).Â  An appellate court must apply the same standard when reviewing the trial judgeâ€™s decision on such motion.Â  See Weir v. Citicorp Natâ€™l Servs., Inc., 312 S.C. 511, 514-15, 435 S.E.2d 864, 867 (1993) (stating standard for appellate court).Â  
  I.Â  Directed Verdicts 
  The Murphys argue the trial court erred in directing verdicts for WCSC and Jefferson Pilot and erred by refusing to direct verdicts in favor of the Murphys.Â  We find the trial court erred in granting WCSC and Jefferson Pilot directed verdicts but did not err in denying the Murphysâ€™ motion for directed verdicts.Â  
  The trial judge explained he had studied the law and general principles of vicarious liability but found this case â€œbizarreâ€ and â€œuniqueâ€ and â€œin the written history of the law there has never been another case like it.â€Â  Without considering the evidence presented as to the vicarious liability of WCSC and Jefferson Pilot, the court concluded:Â  

  To extend vicarious liability to the facts of this case would be beyond reason.Â  If there is any principle guiding the common law, it is reason.Â  There is no reason or public policy to extend the principle of vicarious liability to the facts of this case.Â  I grant the motion for a directed verdict on behalf of WCSC [and Jefferson Pilot]. 

  We find the trial court erred as a matter of law by granting WCSC and Jefferson Pilot directed verdicts based on public policy without considering the elements of the actions alleged and the evidence introduced at trial.Â  See Phelps, 299 S.C. at 446, 385 S.E.2d at 824 (in reviewing the granting of a directed verdict, the court should determine the elements of the action alleged and whether any evidence existed on each element).Â  
  Although we concur with the trial court that the facts of this case are bizarre, we find the law governing vicarious liability should have been considered in reviewing the motions for directed verdicts.Â  Clearly, there is legal authority that â€œa principal may be held liable for defamatory statements made by an agent acting within the scope of his employment or within the scope of his apparent authority.â€Â  Murray v. Holnam, Inc., 344 S.C. 129, 139, 542 S.E.2d 743, 748 (Ct. App. 2001).Â  â€œUnder fundamental principles of South Carolina law, a master is liable for and is charged with knowledge of the acts and conducts of his servants operating within the scope of their employment.â€Â 
  Gathers v. Harris Teeter Supermarket, Inc., 282 S.C. 220, 227, 317 S.E.2d 748, 753 (Ct. App. 1984).Â  â€œIf the servant is doing some act in furtherance of the masterâ€™s business, he will be regarded as acting within the scope of his employment, although he may exceed his authority.â€Â 
  Crittenden v. Thompson-Walker Co., 288 S.C. 112, 115, 341 S.E.2d 385, 387 (Ct. App. 1986) (citations omitted).Â  If there is doubt as to whether the servant was acting within the scope of his employment, the doubt will be resolved against the master at least to the extent of requiring the question to go to the jury.Â  Id. at 116, 341 S.E.2d at 387.
  â€œAn agency relationship may be established by evidence of actual or apparent authority.â€Â 
  Charleston, S.C. Registry for Golf & Tourism, Inc. v. Young Clement Rivers & Tisdale, LLP,
  359 S.C. 635, 642, 598 S.E.2d 717, 721 (Ct. App. 2004).Â  â€œThe elements which must be proven to establish apparent agency are:Â  (1) that the purported principal consciously or impliedly represented another to be his agent; (2) that there was a reliance upon the representation; and (3) that there was a change of position to the relying partyâ€™s detriment.â€Â  Graves v. Serbin Farms, Inc.,
  306 S.C. 60, 63, 409 S.E.2d 769, 771 (1991).Â  An agency relationship need not be express, but may be implied from the conduct of the parties.Â  Gathers, 282 S.C. at 226, 317 S.E.2d at 752.Â  
  There was conflicting evidence at trial regarding Feldmanâ€™s actual or apparent authority and scope of employment.Â  Neither this court nor the trial court has authority to decide credibility issues or to resolve conflicts in the testimony and evidence when considering a motion for directed verdict.Â  Collins v. Doe, 343 S.C. 119, 125, 539 S.E.2d 62, 64 (Ct. App. 2000), revâ€™d on other grounds, 352 S.C. 462, 574 S.E.2d 739 (2002).Â  The issues of agency relationship and scope of employment are generally for the jury.Â  Crittenden, 288 S.C. at 115, 341 S.E.2d at 387;
  Gathers, 
  282 S.C. at 226, 317 S.E.2d at 752.Â  
  As to Feldmanâ€™s authority and scope of employment, Oâ€™Neill and Waring testified that Feldman told them Wing, the station manager at that time, gave Feldman the authority to write the Letter.Â  Feldman also told Oâ€™Neill that Dan McAlister, counsel for Jefferson Pilot, likely previewed the Letter.Â  The Letter was written on WCSC stationery and in it, Feldman purported to be motivated by a desire to protect Senn, the station, and Jefferson Pilot.Â  
  There was evidence in the record that Feldman had broad authority to speak on behalf of WCSC, enter contracts on behalf of WCSC, respond to viewer complaints, and defend the station in letters to newspaper editors or reporters.Â  However, there was conflicting evidence that Feldman did not have authority. Â Senn testified that Feldman repeatedly told her that the matter was personal and not a WCSC matter.Â  Wing denied he ever reviewed or edited the Letter.Â  
  Both Senn and DuTremble testified they believed Feldman had authority to act on WCSCâ€™s behalf.Â  Senn believed Feldmanâ€™s story regarding the incident on the plane and believed Feldman had the authority to write the Letter.Â  â€œI didnâ€™t ever see him write letters, but I assume he would have the authority.Â  He had the letterhead, but I -- you know, I donâ€™t know.â€Â  Senn also testified after she received a copy of the letter she gave it to DuTremble.Â  She then told DuTremble that she heard for years that Elizabeth talked badly about her, â€œBut then I finally had something in writing on Channel 5 letterhead.Â  So I gave it to my lawyer.â€Â  
  DuTrembleâ€™s testimony also indicates he believed Feldman had authority to make the defamatory statements.Â  DuTremble testified in camera:[2]  

  When I went to see Don Feldman, I went to see him as a potential witness.Â  I did not have in my mind anything to do with his position as news director.Â  
  However, when you read [the Letter and the civil agreement], together, itâ€™s obvious that Don Feldman is acting in his position as news director, as an employee for the station, because to give effect ---
  [The Court]:Â  No question thatâ€™s what his job was.
  [DuTremble]:Â  Exactly.Â  To give effect to the civil agreement, he had to have that authority.Â Â  

  DuTremble later testified:Â  

  I mean, Don Feldman was -- you know, he was a member of the community.Â  He was -- he was known in the community.Â  He was news director, a person of some authority apparently.Â  So he carried some indicia of reliability with him . . . .

  Acting on this belief, DuTremble wrote the October 4, 1999 letter to Wall, Elizabethâ€™s attorney.Â  
  We find the questions of agency and scope of employment were issues for the jury to decide.Â  Therefore, the trial court did not err in denying the Murphysâ€™ motion for directed verdicts but erred in directing verdicts in favor of WCSC and Jefferson Pilot.Â  
  II.Â  Ratification
  The Murphys also argue WCSC and Jefferson Pilotâ€™s ratification of Feldmanâ€™s acts warranted submission of the case to the jury.Â  We find this issue is not properly preserved for our review.Â  In order for an issue to be preserved for appellate review, with few exceptions, it must be raised to and ruled upon by the trial judge.Â 
  Lucas v. Rawl Family Ltd. Pâ€™ship, 359 S.C. 505, 511, 598 S.E.2d 712, 715 (2004).Â  The Murphys did not assert the argument of ratification to the trial court or in their Rule 59(e) motion to alter or amend the judgment.Â  Because the Murphys raised this argument for the first time on appeal, we find it is not properly preserved for our review.Â  
  III.Â  Admission of Evidence 
  The Murphys argue the trial court erred in excluding the testimony of Dale DuTremble.[3]Â  The decision whether or not to admit testimony into evidence is within the sound discretion of the trial court and will not be disturbed on appeal absent an abuse of that discretion.Â 
  Am. Fed. Bank v. Number One Main Joint Venture, 321 S.C. 169, 174, 467 S.E.2d 439, 442 (1996).Â  
  The trial court found DuTrembleâ€™s testimony related to Feldmanâ€™s authority at the time he met with DuTremble and Senn rather than Feldmanâ€™s authority at the time he wrote the Letter.Â  The court found the testimony relevant, but the admission of the testimony would confuse the jury, outweighing its probative value.Â  Accordingly, after consideration of Rules 701 and 403, SCRE, the trial court excluded the testimony.Â  
  Rule 701, SCRE, states: 

  If the witness is not testifying as an expert, the witnessâ€™ testimony in the form of opinions or inferences is limited to those opinions or inferences which (a) are rationally based on the perception of the witness, (b) are helpful to a clear understanding of the witnessâ€™ testimony or the determination of a fact in issue, and (c) do not require special knowledge, skill, experience or training.

  Rule 403, SCRE, provides:Â  â€œAlthough relevant, evidence may be excluded if its probative value is substantially outweighed by the danger of unfair prejudice, confusion of the issues, or misleading the jury, or by considerations of undue delay, waste of time, or needless presentation of cumulative evidence.â€ 
  
 In this case, DuTremble was testifying as a fact witness.Â  His testimony was relevant to his perceptions and helpful to a clear understanding of a fact in issue.Â  We fail to see undue prejudice to the defendants.Â  Accordingly, we find the trial court abused its discretion in excluding this portion of DuTrembleâ€™s testimony.Â  
  CONCLUSION
  For the foregoing reasons, the matter is affirmed in part, reversed in part, and remanded for proceedings consistent with this opinion.
  AFFIRMED IN PART, REVERSED IN PART, AND REMANDED.Â  
  GOOLSBY and HUFF,
  JJ., concur.

[1] Â Â Â Â Â Â  Elizabeth is referred to in the record as both Elizabeth Murphy and Elizabeth Stuckey.Â  We refer to her as Elizabeth.Â  
[2] Â Â Â Â Â Â  The trial court denied the Murphysâ€™ request to enter this testimony into evidence.Â  However, the Murphys challenge the trial courtâ€™s ruling in this appeal and we find the trial court erred in excluding this testimony.Â  
[3] Â Â Â Â Â Â  We decline to address any other evidentiary issue on appeal.Â  See Dixon v. Ford, 362 S.C. 614, 608 S.E.2d 879 (Ct. App. 2005) (declining to address evidentiary issue in action remanded for new trial).
